{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "nr": 1, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-08-31T17:17:48Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gd6v7134AUa", "data": "llzfix8mjs41jl", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-08-31T17:17:48Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gd6v7134AUa", "subject": "Welcome to Piazza!", "created": "2023-08-31T17:17:48Z", "content": " Piazza is a Q&A platform designed to get you great answers from classmates and instructors fast. We've put together this list of tips you might find handy as you get started:
  1. Ask questions! The best way to get answers is to ask questions! Ask questions on Piazza rather than emailing your teaching staff so everyone can benefit from the response (and so you can get answers from classmates who are up as late as you are).
  2. Edit questions and answers wiki-style. Think of Piazza as a Q&A wiki for your class. Every question has just a single students' answer that students can edit collectively (and a single instructors’ answer for instructors).
  3. Add a followup to comment or ask further questions. To comment on or ask further questions about a post, start a followup discussion. Mark it resolved when the issue has been addressed, and add any relevant information back into the Q&A above.
  4. Go anonymous. Shy? No problem. You can always opt to post or edit anonymously.
  5. Tag your posts. It's far more convenient to find all posts about your Homework 3 or Midterm 1 when the posts are tagged. Type a “#” before a key word to tag. Click a blue tag in a post or the question feed to filter for all posts that share that tag.
  6. Format code and equations. Adding a code snippet? Click the pre or tt button in the question editor to add pre-formatted or inline teletype text. Mathematical equation? Click the Fx button to access the LaTeX editor to build a nicely formatted equation.
  7. View and download class details and resources.
Click the Course Page button in your top bar to access the class syllabus, staff contact information, office hours details, and course resources—all in one place! Contact the Piazza Team anytime with questions or comments at team@piazza.com. During the first lecture, we created a system of coordinates to describe the position of a cell in a game of tic-tac-toe. We decided that the top-left cell would be (1, 1) in a two dimensional grid, (1,1,1) in three dimensinons and (1,1,1,1) in four dimensions. Is there a mathematical reason for choosing 1 as the first value? Why did we not choose 0?

(EDIT: Posted an english version of my original question)

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "Choix de valeur pour le premier carré dans les grilles de tic-tac-toe", "created": "2023-09-08T21:54:56Z", "content": "Pendant le premier cours magistral, nous avons créé un système de cordonnées pour décrire la position d'une cellule dans un jeu de tic-tac-toe. Nous avons décidé que la cellule dans le coin supérieur gauche serait (1, 1) dans une grille à deux dimensions, (1, 1, 1) à trois dimensions et (1, 1, 1, 1) à quatre dimensions. Est-ce qu'il y avait un raison mathématique pour choisir 1 pour le premier carré dans un ligne? Pourquoi pas utiliser 0?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 310, "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "It's usually just easier to use 1 instead of 0  (we count starting from 1, after all). ", "created": "2023-09-08T22:07:56Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Tonoy Shah", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukwnk52d3dr", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "j7cet0vf2dw4k8", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ukwnk52d3dr"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmb5eujtcmm1u6", "updated": "2023-09-10T00:17:23Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-08T23:22:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Camelia Karimianpour", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljq411p5fwa5il", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-08T23:23:23Z", "content": "

Hi!

I'm pretty sure it was just to create a convention (one is pretty intuitive for most people) for the class so we're all on the same page. I don't see a reason why any other starting value wouldn't work. 

Hope this helps!

I think tm+sn is enough."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Isabella Lu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm17re22zwt4vm", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 318, "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "to write an equation of line in R3 you only need tm + sn but for planes you need three points.", "created": "2023-09-10T15:11:14Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "ljqmhr1vwkc1b0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Thanks!

But plane is plane, I think no matter in what dimensional space, it can be created by two vectors combination. and all of the new vectors after combination combine to be the plane.

", "created": "2023-09-10T15:20:38Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lm44343jfuy70y", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lmdlqrrmyle75f", "updated": "2023-09-10T15:24:30Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmdleort38b6n8", "updated": "2023-09-10T21:09:08Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "@JinghanGao The vector b acts as a “translation” vector that determines the position of the plane in R3. The plane tm + sn always passes through the origin (where b = [0, 0, 0]. This linear combination combines to be all the planes that pass through the origin, but does not describe all planes in R3 as planes in R3 do not necessarily have to include the point (0, 0, 0). So, to describe all planes in R3, we need a position vector (b) and two vectors that lie on the plane (m and n).", "created": "2023-09-10T15:34:44Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Linda Gao(JingHan)", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm44343jfuy70y", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Kushal Chaturvedi", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukpy21d92to", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Jenny Chung", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul1bsu483t3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "lm7ul026hxa3os", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures"], "nr": 29, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-11T14:41:06Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukdq3yn71r0", "data": "lmezrsdn8112e5", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-11T14:41:06Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ljv7m5l01vv4yy", "data": "lmfctfavmy922n", "to": "lmezrsdi6152e4", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-09-11T20:46:18Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lmgwtc9d45v2ex", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-09-12T22:53:52Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lmgwu0a2qjk3ts", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-09-12T22:54:23Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lmgwvqoxnaj71u", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-09-12T22:55:44Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukdq3yn71r0", "subject": "Subsets vs. Equality of sets", "created": "2023-09-11T14:41:06Z", "content": "Today at the end of class we used set notation to show where is reachable using the subway and TTC. Initially we said that the areas reachable were a subset of R^2, but at the end that was changed to be equal to R^2. As I understand R^2  represents all 2d points, and when you set two sets equal to each other then that means that they are both subsets of each other. So, how is R^2 a subset of all the points reachable by the subway and TTC?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Rafael Jabbour", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "llz9oew735074e", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 207, "children": [{"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-11T20:46:18Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-12T22:55:44Z", "content": "

I think like this:

Because:

1,each element of the 2D point contains two unknown number('a' and 'b'),

2,the two formula that formed by 'a' and 'b' are not parallel to each other('3a+b' and 'a+2b'),

means they need two function to solve, and only have one certain solution.

Every number of R can be plug into the function and get one solution,so the final answer =R



geometrically: let's say vector A is in red (alongside negative) and vector B is blue (alongside its negative). below are all the possible vector additions of +-A and +-B.

you can scale these vectors to create any point in one of those four parallelograms. since you could scale these vectors to infinity, it's more or less like four infinitely sized parallelograms expanding from the origin. which would cover the entire cartesian plane.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-12T22:54:23Z", "content": "

There is not much we can control regarding calculator use on assessments that are not proctored and there is a no calculator policy for midterms and final exams. 

That being said, assessments such as written homeworks and Webwork are great opportunities for practice. Hence, I would strongly recommend only using calculators to verify your solutions. 

Hope this helps.

Hello! Could someone please explain why for perpendicular vectors the dot product of 2 vectors is equal to 0? 

I know for the equation if you put in 90 degrees into cos(x), it will become 0, but is there any way to visualize it?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 225, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-12T02:44:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Joanna Xu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul5tcme148v", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Justin Altimari", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukzt7hwa3o3", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Katy Mezei", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukw8u2jp3cd", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Jenny Chung", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul1bsu483t3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-12T02:45:16Z", "content": "

you can think of dot product geometrically as the amount of overlap of two vectors or like the shadow of one vector on another. If they are perpendicular, then there is no overlap at all, so the dot product is zero! 

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-12T02:44:42Z", "content": "

Dear professors of MAT188,

For problem 2 on the assignment, would a vector perpendicular to v have its leg starting from some point along v? Or will the set containing all vectors perpendicular to v include vectors that do not directly intersect it or start from a point along v?

The reason why I ask this is because of part 2 of the problem, which tells me to sketch the set to be detailed in part 1. If the set contains only perpendicular vectors which have their foot on v, then the diagram can be drawn. However, if the set contains perpendicular vectors that do not have a foot on v, then the sketch becomes very difficult to draw.

Thank you, Yunfan.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Properties of perpendicular vectors", "created": "2023-09-12T17:28:51Z", "content": "

Dear professors of MAT188,

For problem 2 on the assignment, would a vector perpendicular to v have its leg starting from some point along v? Or will the set containing all vectors perpendicular to v include vectors that do not directly intersect it or start from a point along v?

The reason why I ask this is because of part 2 of the problem, which tells me to sketch the set to be detailed in part 1. If the set contains only perpendicular vectors which have their foot on v, then the diagram can be drawn. However, if the set contains perpendicular vectors that do not have a foot on v, then the sketch becomes very difficult to draw.

Thank you, Yunfan.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["hw1"], "nr": 48, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-13T02:58:22Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lmh5jrt3pqy2bv", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-13T02:58:22Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk5b582wwb", "data": "lmhooajbv2y4j6", "to": "lmh5jrt0a192bu", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-09-13T11:53:46Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lmjordp5nw824a", "to": "lmh5jrt0a192bu", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-09-14T21:31:43Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Solving Questions", "created": "2023-09-13T02:58:22Z", "content": "With regard to the homework, I am able to solve the questions with my knowledge of vectors, planes, and systems of equations. However, I am having trouble explaining how I solved the question or putting my thoughts into words. So, I was wondering whether there is a process I can follow to help me solidify the explanations when solving."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["hw1", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Xianshuo Zang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul8cpbly4hi", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Vir Patel", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk5b582wwb", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 168, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-13T11:53:46Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk5b582wwb", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-13T11:53:46Z", "content": "Having a look at the structure of example solutions in a Linear Algebra textbook was recommended or seeking help from the resources available at the MLC."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lmhooaj7tm04j5", "config": {"editor": "plain"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-14T21:31:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Justin Altimari", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukzt7hwa3o3", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-14T21:31:43Z", "content": "One strategy is to assume you are explaining your work to a classmate who doesn't know how to solve these questions. This imaginary classmate asks "why?" or "How do you know"\u00a0 at the end of every sentence you say. So, you have to step back and explain to them "why" you took that step. Once you go through this exercise, your next exercise is to summarize your explanation into a coherent minimal paragraph made of full sentences that contains all the necessary information.\u00a0

Hello Instructors,


At the end of our MAT188 lecture on the 13th, we practiced finding the angle between 2 vectors illustrated as blocks in Minecraft. I am confused why are we writing the vectors as if they are 3 dimensional (u,v,w) even though they are clearly 2 dimensions, since finding the angle between vectors in 3 different dimensions is confusing as we do not know which angle between which vectors are we looking for...

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 145, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-14T14:07:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brian Tobing", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk5qionkxj", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljq411p5fwa5il", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-14T14:09:58Z", "content": "

Hi!

As you said, we're looking at vectors on a cube similar to one on Minecraft. Though we're restricted to a 2D representation of the cube on a chalkboard, in Minecraft, the blocks are 3D, no? 

To find the angle between two vectors in 3D just imagine the plane the two vectors create, and the angle you're looking for is the angle between the two vectors on that plane.

I hope this helps!

Firstly, I wanted to ask if, at this point keeping with the lectures and required readings, we should be capable of fully completing the written homework of the week. I am working on it now, and am finding it to be very challenging, and am wondering if I simply do not understand the material, or if we haven't covered it in depth. I've looked at all the questions, and most start with me saying, 'oh yeah, I can do this' and end with 'what on Earth is this asking me to do?' I'm wondering if I'm the only one with this feeling.


Secondly, I was wondering about Problem 2 on the HW set:

The question says to find ALL vectors in R3 perpendicular to v=[1, 3, -1].
After a short while, using u*v=0 (dot product), I boiled it down to a set notation, which generalizes for multiple (so far looks like infinite) solutions.

However, I was shocked to see that the next part asks to draw a sketch. I saw someone ask the same question, but I don't believe it was about the infinite solutions.

I'm wondering if I am just completely confused about the question or have a wrong solution, or if we haven't gotten to this level of sketching yet? I'm wondering if I'm getting ahead of myself here.

I was hoping someone could give me a hand or perhaps some words of wisdom.

Cheers,

They are designed so that you discuss them with your peers and the teaching team and push your limits. Typically, they will not contain questions that you have seen before.\u00a0

At this point, after some work and discussion, you should be able to do Q1 and 2. you can also explore Q3 and 4 and set up equations for them. You will need your next week's material to comfortably solve them.\u00a0

Q2: you are on the right track thinking there are infinitely many vectors perpendicular to the given one. To visualize them and draw a sketch, assume they are all in standard positions. Then only think about the tip of the vectors, what geometrical object do they form? In my view, I believe that the elements L, M, and N consist of numerous vectors sharing the same direction but varying in length. Since the starting points of these vectors are unspecified, their tips can be located anywhere. Therefore, I do not agree with the answer that L represents a line passing through (0,0). Additionally, I consider the elements of O as vectors, with their endpoints forming a line, but the set itself is not a line.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 141, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-16T20:07:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mahreen Naila", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uklh38no2ft", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Jaewon Shon", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukwctwd63cu", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-16T20:07:57Z", "content": "

Hello, 

To define a plane we need two non-parallel vectors, which is Professor Chan's result. The starting form (Cartesian form) already defines a plane, but this exercise is just getting us to write it in a different format.

Notice that from the Cartesian equation of the plane (x-2y+3z=0), we can define any variable using the other two variables. Professor Chan chose to define x in terms of y and z, which became x = 2y-3z. Now we can write x = 2y - 3z, y = y, z = z, and we can group the same variables together into two vectors (so the first is <2y, y, 0> and the second is <-3z, 0, z>). If we write the two vectors based on the variable (one only has y, the other only has z), we can factor out the variable (or scalar multiple) and we will be left with two vectors (y* <2, 1, 0>) and (z* <-3, 0, 1>). This defines a plane provided that y and z can be any real number. 

Since writing the scalars as y and z can be confusing and unconventional, Professor Chan let y = a and let z = b at the start of the process, so you can imagine any instance of a in his writing is y, and b is z. 

Sorry if there is an error, hope that helps

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7uklh38no2ft", "lm7ukwctwd63cu"], "children": [], "id": "lmmgndgm2t674a", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmmepbxe76e7x", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716175842502, "default_anonymity": "no"}

For the first question it says augmented matrix. But for the formula, it doesn't have a augmented column at the end.

For the second question it also says reduced echelon form. But on the Pre-class reading, there is only row echelon form (REF) and reduced row echelon form (RREF).

So I'm really confused about this two question, could anyone explain them? Thanks!

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukanouw11i9", "subject": "About the question in the PCEII part 1", "created": "2023-09-17T02:28:40Z", "content": "

For the first question it says augmented matrix. But for the formula, it doesn't have a augmented column at the end.

For the second question it also says reduced echelon form. But on the Pre-class reading, there is only row echelon form (REF) and reduced row echelon form (RREF).

So I'm really confused about this two question, could anyone explain them? Thanks!

The line that separates the augmented column is just a hint to indicate the given matrix is to be thought of as the augmented matrix of a system. It is not an essential part of the notation. Given any matrix, you can think of it as an augmented matrix of a system, or coefficient matrix of (a different) system, or neither. 

Reduce Echelon Form is the same as Reduce Row Echelon Form

Your go-to page is Lecture Schedule, under the Lecture Schedule (all sections) module on Querucs. 

There you will find a table that contains our weekly schedule. In particular, you see your pre-class adn post-class readings, and link to your PCE check-ins. PCE check-ins are short quizzes. You are expected to click on them only after you prepare for the upcoming lecture. You can prepare by reading the relavant sections of the textbook, or the preclass reading, or only the essential part of the pre-class reading. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures"], "nr": 90, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-17T18:29:30Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lmnskm7vp6y4m5", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-17T18:29:30Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "hlnuq2z6msj5y1", "data": "lmo08lpcmu7go", "to": "lmnskm7sigi4m4", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-09-17T22:04:07Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "LEC0106 Cross-Product Confusion", "created": "2023-09-17T18:29:30Z", "content": "

Hello!

The last lecture of LEC0106 talked about cross-product. I still don't understand the last part of this derivation.

How and why does the line I underlined in red change to |w|^2 ? Why should we let t be +/- (u2v1 - u1v2)? It seems that u2v1 and u1v2 are not involved in the entire derivation.

Thanks in advance!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Moosa Saboor", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukzdvejp3mt", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Suzen Bao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukh5cyqz224", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 132, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-17T22:04:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "hlnuq2z6msj5y1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-17T22:04:07Z", "content": "

There was a lot of arithmetic skipped here, so I was not able to make it very clear.  After the red line, what you would do is substitute in the coordinates for $$\vec{u}$$ and $$\vec{v}$$ and keep simplifying until it's somewhat nicer.

Then, you take $$\vec{w}$$ on its own (that is, we now have a new set of calculations) and find the square of its magnitude.  After a few steps, you will see the value you came up with for $$A^2$$ show up.  When you factor it out, you get what we have under that red line.

Since we wanted to get $$A^2=|\vec{w}|^2$$, that is what determines the value for $$t$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lmo08lp7nhi7gn", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ukzdvejp3mt", "lm7ukh5cyqz224"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmnskm7sigi4m4", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716175853309, "default_anonymity": "no"}

We have different numbers for this question. So I'll just write steps to get the answer if that helps.

1. Draw a triangle diagram if it helps

2. Evaluate length of a, b, c

For example, to find length a if D (1,1,1) and E (1,-4,2)

$$a=\sqrt{(1-1)^2+(1+4)^2+(1-2)^2}=\sqrt{26}$$

You have to find length b and c

2. Use cosine law to find the angle D, E, F

For example, to find angle D:

$$c^2=a^2+b^2-2abcos\angle D$$

Then you just have to find the angle in radians

You need to use cosine law to find angle E and F

Just to add, you have to use 3 decimals. That's it. I used 3 and it still worked out.

Hello,

I attempted the first question of 1.2 exercises in the textbook. I got the first two correct but I didn’t understand why the textbook put the z coordinate in as the answer. They put: $$\begin{bmatrix} x\\ y\\ z \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 13+10t\\ -8-8t\\ t \end{bmatrix}$$ and I don’t really get why they would include the z part because we only had 2 equations to start off with. Was there something that went wrong when I was solving it? I’ve included my working below as well.

Thank you.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 118, "children": [{"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-18T00:07:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Wareesha Ahsan Qureshi", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukfk6s2j1x2", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-18T00:12:08Z", "content": "You put z at the end because your system of equations has 3 unique variables. However, the answer key indicates that it should be parallel.\u00a0"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Arman Zaher", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "llyg15mtpra3qg", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 128, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-18T02:03:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Camelia Karimianpour", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-18T02:03:41Z", "content": "

Keep in mind that when you substitute in a parameter, you're getting a position vector in return. For this context you can still treat it like a point on a line. Hence, whether the lines are parallel would actually depend on the direction vector, which is the vector that you are multiplying the parameter (t or k) by. The direction vector is essentially the slope of your line. If you look at the direction vector of line 1 and 2, I'm sure you'll realize something about them.\u00a0

\n

\n

Generally to see if two lines intersect, you'd need to see if a point in a line exists on another. You can follow a procedure similar to what you've done in grade 9 and 10, or you can utilize the parametric equations of the two lines.\u00a0

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Textbook 1.2 Exercise Question 3", "created": "2023-09-18T02:34:56Z", "content": "

Hello,

If we were to use Gauss-Jordan elimination, why would the following equation not have any solutions? Is it because there isn’t another equation to solve it simultaneously with?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 110, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-18T03:06:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Ali Alizada", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l79f0oonxcv9r", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljq411p5fwa5il", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-18T03:06:45Z", "content": "

Hi!

Gauss Jordan elimination is more so used for a system of linear equations (ie. when you have several). It doesn't make much sense to apply it to a single linear equation. If you simply want to find any solution for this you can "arbitrarily" assign two of the three variables any value and then solve for the third; there is an infinite amount of solutions. For example. setting y and z equal to zero would give you x=4, making [4, 0, 0] a solution.

Hope this helps!

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["hw1"], "nr": 106, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-18T17:03:31Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukr5fky52wv", "data": "lmp4xvslwp46f6", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-18T17:03:31Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "data": "lmphq38sii71h1", "to": "lmp4xvsh3ic6f5", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-09-18T23:01:22Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukr5fky52wv", "subject": "Written homework problem 2: origin point of perpendicular vectors?", "created": "2023-09-18T17:03:31Z", "content": "

For problem two, the written work says to identify all vectors perpendicular to v in R^3. Does this mean vectors that originate from the arrow

<1, 3, -1>, or just the tip of the vector, or in all R^3 spaces?

For example, the plane defined by the normal vector <-1, -3, 1> contains vectors perpendicular to v, but they don't originate from v, the line of action would need to be extended.

Moreover, the plane defined by the vector <.5, 1.5, -.5> also contains vectors perpendicular to v, but they only originate from the arrow and not the tip.

Which senarios should I include in my solution?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["hw1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 151, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-18T23:01:22Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-18T23:01:22Z", "content": "Technically, all vectors are defined from the origin. We draw vectors as coming from the tips of other vectors to illustrate certain concepts, but it wouldn't exactly be correct to say that's where they 'originate'. So, (1, 3, -1) should be a vector defined as coming from the origin, and any vector perpendicular to it should also come from (0, 0, 0)"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lmphq38ocwu1h0", "config": {"editor": "plain"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmp4xvsh3ic6f5", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716175870586, "default_anonymity": "no"}

For Written Homework 1, problem set 2, we are meant to find all vectors perpendicular to a given v = [1,3,-1]. Since there is an infinite number of vectors perpendicular to v, how are we able to complete part 2 of the problem where we are asked to sketch our answer? I saw a previous response to a similar question suggesting we consider the shape made by the vectors' tips. This makes sense but I'd appreciate a little more guidance. Thank you in advance.

\n

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["hw1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 163, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-19T19:40:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-19T19:40:26Z", "content": "You are right thinking that you have a set of infinitely many vectors. Apriory you can visualize them drawn from any point in the space. However, that will not give you a coherent object. Instead, imagine them all drawn from the origin. You can draw a few such vectors and imagine the ed shape they make.\u00a0"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lmqpzj0zi4n4f", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "For problem 2 question 1, can we express our answer simply as a scalar equation?", "created": "2023-09-20T02:18:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I think so. "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork_and_gateway"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mahreen Naila", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uklh38no2ft", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 161, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-21T01:23:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-21T01:23:37Z", "content": "The matrix A is a coefficient matrix - you can tell because it is being used to multiply a vector, so an augmented matrix would not make much sense here (that would imply you are multiplying your answer by the vector). If you want to solve this using a matrix, you can augment it with the zero vector answer (all rows in the augmented column are 0) and insert zero rows (which represent 0 = 0) until you have 4 rows for the 4 variables. From there it is just a matter of rewriting the augmented matrix into an equation form."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lmshoqe2o0d4ew", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "What do you mean by augment it with zero vector. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["webwork_and_gateway"], "nr": 134, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-21T00:25:49Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lmsfmdxk8g66sy", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-21T00:25:49Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lmshwpbvzi77f6", "to": "lmsfmdxhug76sx", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-09-21T01:29:49Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WeBWork 1 Question 2", "created": "2023-09-21T00:25:49Z", "content": "

Hello!
For Question 2 in WeBWork 1, even though I got them correct. I didn't understand why the equation of the line is 3x + 3y = 6, given that vector v = <3,-3>, the point P coordinate is (1,1).

Why not the equation be -3x + 3y = 6? And how did you get 6 on the right side?

Thanks in advance!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork_and_gateway"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Ali Alizada", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l79f0oonxcv9r", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 152, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-21T01:29:49Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Parvin Malekzadeh", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kew77swg4wb5vu", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-21T01:29:49Z", "content": "If you write the equation out in slope-intercept form, you get $$y=-x+b$$ (slope comes from $$\frac {3} {-3}$$, rise over run of v); solving for b by substituting in $$(1,1)$$ you get $$1 = -1 + b \iff 2=b$$, for an overall equation $$y=-x+2$$. If you move the x over to the other side and multiply everything by 3, you get $$3x+3y=6$$."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["kew77swg4wb5vu"], "children": [], "id": "lmshwpbre5z7f5", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["l79f0oonxcv9r"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmsfmdxhug76sx", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716175900804, "default_anonymity": "no"}

", "created": "2023-09-24T00:18:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "ljww2wwy5x05wq", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lmwpoc3zzb84a0", "updated": "2023-09-24T00:18:20Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmwibyhmcp03zp", "updated": "2023-09-24T00:18:20Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-23T22:19:05Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kf2z2j444pg31s", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-23T22:19:05Z", "content": "

Consider that, by definition, a function $$f: X \rightarrow Y$$ must at the very least map $$a \in X$$ to a unique element $$b \in Y$$. This is what we would state as $$f(a) = b$$.

More specifically, it should never be that case that there exists $$b_1, b_2 \in Y$$, such that $$b_1 \neq b_2$$ and $$b_1 = f(a) = b_2$$.

Now, ask yourself if $$f(t) = 0$$ fits this definition?

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["hw1"], "nr": 158, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-23T23:41:52Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukl4hr792eu", "data": "lmwodf6x5ee4d0", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-23T23:41:52Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lmxsm2vxmd52pj", "to": "lmwodf6ucaz4cz", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-09-24T18:28:20Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukl4hr792eu", "subject": "Written Homework question 4 clarification", "created": "2023-09-23T23:41:52Z", "content": "

In question 4 of the homework we are using position vectors r1,r2,r3. Do we calculate the vectors from the origin (0,0) or do we calculate them from rcm (2,2)?

(For example is r1 = (1,2) or (-1,0))

I originally did the question from the origin however conceptually it makes more sense to me that it would be from the point where the mass is.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["hw1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 135, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-24T18:28:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-24T18:28:20Z", "content": "

Judging from the image attached to the question, the position vectors are calculated from the origin and the resultant COM position vector will also be from the origin.

From a physical standpoint, when you use this equation you are trying to take the « average » of the masses at the points given relative to some origin, so it makes sense that the result should also be relative to that same origin.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 163, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-24T16:37:52Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lmxoo0e62au92", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-24T16:37:52Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lmxtqvrbekc5sc", "to": "lmxoo0e1n9w90", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-09-24T19:00:04Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kehnb0fgkg55og", "data": "lmxugl1czyl35", "to": "lmxoo0e1n9w90", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-09-24T19:20:03Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "PCE week3 introduce", "created": "2023-09-24T16:37:52Z", "content": "I still can't get what's the difference between codomain and range. Thanks for reply."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 137, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-24T19:00:04Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Linda Gao(JingHan)", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm44343jfuy70y", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Arthur Chan", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kehnb0fgkg55og", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Armita Eskandar-Zadeh", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lk1mskbi2048w", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-24T19:00:04Z", "content": "

The codomain can be thought of as the set of values that a function could theoretically output, and the range the set of values it actually outputs. As an example, consider $$f(x)=x^2$$, then $$f$$ is defined as $$f:R\mapsto R$$ (takes a real number and gives back a real number); the codomain is just the set of all real numbers, but we can constrain that further to just the positive and zero real numbers for the range.

This feels like an arbitrary choice, but there are some reasons for it; namely sometimes it is incredibly difficult to compute the range (say for a 6th degree polynomial) but we still want to say something about the outputs, that's where the codomain is useful. I think this discussion gives fairly good reasons for why we separate codomain and range: https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/777563/codomain-of-a-function

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm44343jfuy70y", "kehnb0fgkg55og", "lk1mskbi2048w"], "children": [], "id": "lmxtqvr78ld5sb", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-24T19:20:03Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kehnb0fgkg55og", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-24T19:20:03Z", "content": "

Indeed that is a good explanation. Codomain is just the space we are mapping to, not necessarily excluding the parts of the codomain space that the transformation cannot map to. For example, a 3 by 2 matrix represents a linear transformation where the codomain is R^3. However, because it represents the span of 2 R^3 vectors is only a plane, but not all of R^3.

We will use the term "image" (which is a more appropriate term than range) to represent all the places we can go.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lmxugl1b9bx34", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmxoo0e1n9w90", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716175932101, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork_and_gateway"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 122, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-26T01:40:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-26T01:40:13Z", "content": "Try to mentally connect the geometry of the system to the equations. For example, if x = 0, y = 0, and z = 0, you know these are 3 planes that should be perpendicular each other. Which image does this best correspond with? If z = 0 and z-1 = -1, for example, how are these planes geometrically related to each other? What image best displays this relationship (i.e., \u201cshould the planes be perpendicular?\u201d, \u201cshould only two of them be perpendicular?\u201d, \u201care any of the planes equal?\u201d are the types of questions you should be asking). Note that some might be ambiguous and may require guessing.\u00a0"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lmznhc2tnup61x", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "First of all, thanks for your reply. But this question is asking about the solution and how many variables that are needed. Could you please help me with this?", "created": "2023-09-26T01:46:39Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lm7ul8cpbly4hi", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I apologize for not analyzing the image closely enough. For this question, you should think about what kind of solution the system has. Is it consistent or inconsistent? If consistent, how do the planes intersect? Do they share only one common point? Do they intersect at a line? Is there a whole plane of solutions? Think about the solution of just two of the planes. Then see if the third plane intersects anywhere where the first two do.\u00a0

Once you identify the geometry of the solution, remember that lines are one dimensional and planes are two dimensional. What should this say about the number of free variables needed to define a plane, or perhaps a line?
", "created": "2023-09-26T01:52:07Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Arthur Chan", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kehnb0fgkg55og", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["kehnb0fgkg55og"], "id": "lmznwmtijo320", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2023-09-26T03:29:42Z", "config": {}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmznplqfhn653a", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2023-09-26T02:07:10Z", "config": {}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "To define a line, we need one variable. To define a plane , we need two variables? Is that correct?", "created": "2023-09-26T01:57:22Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lm7ul8cpbly4hi", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "You\u2019ll learn best if you refer to the PCEs and try to make sense if it yourself using your knowledge of matrices and rank. What can be said about the solution space if there is one free variable? How can we mathematically represent this solution? What if there are two free variables? How does this appear in a matrix? The week 2 PCEs answer these questions in great detail.

It is not good practice to blindly believe that \u201ca line is one dimensional so it must occur when there is one free variable\u201d, for example. Use what you now know to confirm this for yourself.
", "created": "2023-09-26T02:54:24Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lmzq4qatl7f50i", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2023-09-26T02:54:24Z", "config": {}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Recall how lines and planes are represented in vector form and how many free variables there are.", "created": "2023-09-26T03:31:51Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "kehnb0fgkg55og", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lmzrgvvg8m922d", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2023-09-26T03:31:51Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmzo3dszz41d1", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2023-09-26T03:31:58Z", "config": {}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-26T16:37:04Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "k172xqbmuxc3m", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-26T16:37:04Z", "content": "

Good question! If you're still wondering about this, then the first thing I would suggest is trying the lower dimensional 2D case first. How can you determine whether two linear equations in 2 variables have a solution *in terms of their graphs?* That is what we are doing here, but in 3 variables. The idea is the exact same, but you get more interesting behaviour here.\u00a0

\n

Let me know if you have any further questions, or if you would like me to reveal more.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["webwork_and_gateway"], "nr": 172, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-26T02:41:31Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljo7bpzud532hb", "data": "lmzpo5y6naq6ae", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-26T02:41:31Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lmzpt451qxc4mv", "to": "lmzpo5y2akl6ad", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-09-26T02:45:22Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ljo7bpzud532hb", "to": "lmzpo5y2akl6ad", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-09-26T02:59:23Z", "cid": "lmzqb4vbf4a6yr"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljo7bpzud532hb", "subject": "Isn't this impossible?", "created": "2023-09-26T02:41:31Z", "content": "

\n

Isn't this impossible? If we assume that the matrix represents column vectors instead of row vectors (since it would be impossible to do the multiplication otherwise), the matrix-vector multiplication should give a vector the size of the rows in this case, i.e. in R2, right??\u00a0

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork_and_gateway"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 130, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-26T02:45:22Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Jack Sloan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljo7bpzud532hb", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Arthur Chan", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kehnb0fgkg55og", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-26T02:45:22Z", "content": "Remember that A is being multiplied by x, not b. So x will be 2 dimensional (though this is not specified in the question, it is assumed) but b will still have 3 components.

A maps a vector in 2 space to a vector in 3 space, hence why A is a 3x2 matrix.
"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["ljo7bpzud532hb", "kehnb0fgkg55og"], "children": [], "id": "lmzpt44xaap4mu", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Oh yes of course thank you!\u00a0", "created": "2023-09-26T02:59:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "ljo7bpzud532hb", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmzqb4vbf4a6yr", "updated": "2023-09-26T03:24:22Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmzpo5y2akl6ad", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716175941811, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["webwork_and_gateway"], "nr": 173, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-26T03:08:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lmzqm9cv45nwx", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-26T03:08:02Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kehnb0fgkg55og", "data": "lmzrcrwz1xgzs", "to": "lmzqm9ctbh4ww", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-09-26T03:28:39Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "data": "lmzrdisjj1z4hy", "to": "lmzqm9ctbh4ww", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-09-26T03:29:14Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Gateway Practise", "created": "2023-09-26T03:08:02Z", "content": "

Hello,

For this problem, why would our first step be to row reduce A? and how would row reducing help us fin the answers? Are we just assuming that the variables that are represented by the columns in A are x1 x2 x3 x4?

Thank You

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork_and_gateway"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 120, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-26T03:28:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kehnb0fgkg55og", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-26T03:28:39Z", "content": "Remember that matrix-vector multiplication is just another way of representing a linear system of equations."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lmzrcrww69tzr", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-26T03:29:14Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-26T03:29:14Z", "content": "
Yes, the columns of A correspond to variables x1, x2, x3, and x4 because the matrix represents a system of equation in terms of these variables.

We must row reduce A (augmented with the zero vector, for this particular problem) because we must identify the pivot columns in the RREF. Remember that by definition, the rank of a matrix is the number of pivot columns in the RREF. That’s why it’s absolutely necessary to find the RREF.

When you determine the RRER, you’ll come to notice that x2, x3, and x4 are free variables because their columns are not pivot columns. x1 is a dependent variable because its column is a pivot column. That’s why the solution is written only in terms of the free variables, x2, x3, and x4, as the solution always should be, because these variables can be anything and equation will remain satisfied.
"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lmzrdisibeq4hx", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmzqm9ctbh4ww", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716175942889, "default_anonymity": "no"}

We can only multiply vectors by coefficient matrices. That’s why they’re called coefficient matrices! But we cannot write the coefficient matrix as a sum of vectors. We can only interpret matrix-vector multiplication to be the equivalent of setting up a linear system. Notice how I said matrix-vector multiplication! A matrix itself is not a linear system. ONLY when it is multiplied by a vector (or if that kind of operation is being assumed, in the case with an augmented matrix). "}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ln114sg6y574jx", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-27T00:55:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-27T00:55:47Z", "content": "Your vector $$\vec x$$ here is indeed $$\begin{bmatrix}x\\y\\z\end{bmatrix}$$. Instructor's Answer Response: I'm still slightly lost. If we go from the linear system to the coefficient matrix and then compute for  A[xyz] (shown in red), how does it relate to the linear system we started (shown in blue).

Student's Answer Response: 

"But we cannot write the coefficient matrix as a sum of vectors." => How so? Can't it be done through linear combination? 

"A matrix itself is not a linear system." => Isn't matrix a different way to represent a linear system? 

", "created": "2023-09-27T01:16:33Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "You’re right. Multiplying a vector by a matrix is the equivalent of writing a linear combination of the columns of the matrix with the components of the vector. But, the coefficient matrix itself is not a linear combination of anything. Sure, a matrix is a way of representing a linear system, but it itself is not a linear system. You can think of the matrix as being just the expressions (eg, 2x+3y, x+y, 6x-y), but these expressions are meaningless unless you equate them to something, in which case which you’re solving for xyz by rewritting the matrix in RREF. "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practicals", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nancy Shnoudeh", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukjvoh1c2b2", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Rocky", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l7zca5v3mwo56", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 136, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-27T02:01:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Parvin Malekzadeh", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kew77swg4wb5vu", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-27T02:01:23Z", "content": "

If you multiply out the matrix by a vector in R4, and then set the result to the zero vector, you will end up with a system of two equations (for the two dimensions of the resultant vectors) and four unknowns (for the four of the vector x).

In this case you can show one of your equations is actually equal to the other, leaving you with one equation and four unknowns. If you parameterize the last three (x2, x3, x4), and then solve that equation for x1, you get the answer they show.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["logistics"], "nr": 182, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-27T01:54:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ln13ft40nndob", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-27T01:54:42Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "ln13pbj66zd6mt", "to": "ln13ft3vmvco0", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-09-27T02:02:06Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ln13ft3vmvco0", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-09-27T03:41:44Z", "cid": "ln179gmynm12zx", "uid_a": "a_2"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ln13ft3vmvco0", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-09-27T12:16:26Z", "cid": "ln1pnd4a8gv66y", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ln13ft3vmvco0", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-09-27T12:26:50Z", "cid": "ln1q0qgtsd84rn", "uid_a": "a_2"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "ln2nb0akebm7ph", "to": "ln13ft3vmvco0", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-09-28T03:58:36Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Tips for Row Reducing", "created": "2023-09-27T01:54:42Z", "content": "Is there a specific process or general set of steps that should be followed when row reducing to REF and RREF (what\u2019s the thought process/analysis when tasked with row reducing)? I find myself getting stuck in this process and wondering if there\u2019s only one right way to go about it. Also, how do you know when there is a free variable versus when you can continue manipulating the rows to create a pivot position?\u00a0"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["logistics", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 130, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-27T02:02:06Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-27T02:02:06Z", "content": "I\u2019m sure someone out there has created a horribly complicated flowchart as to how to do this step by step, but, my way of doing it which I find pretty efficient is to just do it column by column. If the first column is 3, 6, 7, then I would \u00a0subtract 2x(first row) from the second row. Then, I would multiply the third row by 3, and then subtract 7x(first row) from it. For the third row, you can also just work with fractions however it may be inconvenient for an exam where calculators are not permitted.

Do the same for the second column, except use the entry in the second row to eliminate the rest of the numbers in that column. And so on.

To know when there are free variables, just read and understand the rules for what classifies a matrix as being in RREF. If a matrix is in RREF, there is no further manipulation needed. All the information would be in front of you. Remember that each matrix has just one unique RREF.
"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ln13pbj31t06mr", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "When going onto the second column, can we use entries from the first row to eliminated the rest of the numbers below? The concept of "direction" is only being used in this question to give the numbers a physical meaning. There is no extra information implied by this physical interpretation however, so the problem is still solvable even if you strip it down to just vectors and matricies.

If you require a physical intuition behind this problem, remember that not all systems represent things quantities same way. In the case of the directions which do not have magnitude 1, it can be thought of as the camera encoding extra information into the magnitude field of the direction vector. Maybe it represents lens focus, zoom level, or shutter speed, but regardless of what it is, it is still necessary to transform to the format it expects and not to what you want it to be (i.e. you do not want to normalize the direction vectors).

Hello MAT188 populace,

VP

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["hw2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 137, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-28T23:36:05Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Camelia Karimianpour", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lke5st586dh3aa", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-28T23:36:05Z", "content": "You need to use the template to solve questions and submit it. Questions list is just to see all the questions in one page. So you just have to print out the template, work on it and submit it!
Hope this helps!
"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["jvbpijsmgxy40f"], "children": [], "id": "ln3td9hm3k06nc", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-29T03:06:24Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-29T03:06:24Z", "content": "Questions lists typically come out before the template, so that you can get started on thinking about the problems. (Edit: retracted misleading answer)

If your issue is arising in part b), there appears to be no real solution using the rotation formula. Regardless of if you try to compose the two transformations using math we have yet to learn in class (as of 29 Sept.) or if you do them one at a time, the equation for transforming $$z$$ to the desired value of $$- \frac {\sqrt {3}} {2}$$ requires complex numbers to solve.

This is not an issue in and of itself, as complex numbers are quite natural for describing rotations. However, as this course has never touched complex numbers, it seems unlikely that it would require their use for a correct answer.

Allowing the matrix to take on arbitrary values produces a solution, but this does not feel like the intended solving path as it no longer holds to the idea of rotating the camera.

Have you tried first rotating in the xy plane and then the xz plane?", "created": "2023-09-30T01:47:18Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ln5dhusxqr16mx", "updated": "2023-09-30T01:47:18Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

If you place the transformation in the xy plane first, then you have another no real solution equation for the y-axis rotation. I think the answer lies in replacing the trigonometric functions with identities instead. As an example in two dimensions:

$$\begin{bmatrix} \cos (\theta) & - \sin (\theta)\\ \sin (\theta) & \cos(\theta) \end{bmatrix}$$ instead is $$\begin{bmatrix} a & \pm \sqrt {1-a^2} \\ \pm \sqrt {1-a^2} & a \end{bmatrix}$$ (where $$\pm$$ is chosen depending on quadrant you want).

This allows you to work with complex solutions without needing to know the definitions for the trigonmetric functions over the complex plane. It is still messy, but it is more doable.

Hello,

I am wondering whether we are permitted to compute the two rotation angles in 4b using a scientific calculator once we derive the first to be arccos(a) + b, or whether we should solve the second angle in terms of arccos(a) + b. Computing the direct angle measure would save a lot of space and computation on the page (unless I am missing a simpler way to derive the second angle once we've found the first). I wrote a + b so I don't write the answer on Piazza. 

*I took the advice from another Piazza question and rotated by xy first after seeing z would require complex solutions

Thanks

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Problem 4b HW2", "created": "2023-09-30T16:26:33Z", "content": "

Hello,

I am wondering whether we are permitted to compute the two rotation angles in 4b using a scientific calculator once we derive the first to be arccos(a) + b, or whether we should solve the second angle in terms of arccos(a) + b. Computing the direct angle measure would save a lot of space and computation on the page (unless I am missing a simpler way to derive the second angle once we've found the first). I wrote a + b so I don't write the answer on Piazza. 

Thanks

yes you can use a calculator on the questions. also yes you can directly use the angle measure and trig ratios as decimals because the question is asking you for the transformations and not the actual angles or the rotation matrix. But be sure to indicate the angle you are using.

It is also possible to replace the trigonmetric functions using the identity $$\sin^2(a) + \cos^2(a) = 1$$, rearranging for one of the functions then substituting. This allows you to avoid decimals altogether and use exact value. See @205_f1 for an example of what this looks like.

Thanks

If so, would proving there is no solution suffice?\u00a0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukmhsyd2ij", "subject": "HW2 Question 4(2)", "created": "2023-10-03T21:19:03Z", "content": "In Question 4 part 2, must the transformations be strictly first being a rotation in the xz-plane and the second being rotation in the xy-plane? Secondly, do these transformations occur simultaneously or the consecutively (one after another)?\u00a0\u00a0"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["hw2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 138, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-03T21:27:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukgl49p220m", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-03T21:27:17Z", "content": "It does not have to be that. IMG_6052.jpeg

Can someone please clarify why the above matrix either may have a unique or no solution. Is the correct answer that the matrix may have no solution since there could be a value in the augmented column in the last row.

IMG_6053.jpeg

For the above picture, I selected the first option, which says answer in green beside it. I did not receive full marks for this question. Is it because they are all true?

IMG_6054.jpeg

For the above question, why did I only receive part marks and not full. I thought that my answers were all correct (the unselected and selected ones), since it’s not a zero, lower triangular or identity matrix. A lower triangle matrix should only have number at the bottom triangle.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Tashrifa Muhit", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm6q97pl63md9", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 113, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-03T22:36:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-03T22:36:28Z", "content": "

1) The correct answer is "may have no solution" since you may get a pivot in the augmented column. 

2) All options are correct

3) A lower triangular matrix has zeros above the main diagonal by definition. This matrix satisfies the definition of a lower triangular matrix.

Hello,

The recent Quercus post says that if we practiced for Gateway I with the use of an RREF calculator but took the test without one, we would have to chance to redo it. If we opt for the retake and we get a lower mark than we did previously, will the new mark be used regardless, or will we still be given the highest mark out of all our attempts?

Thank you.

That is, do we have to first rotate in the xz plane and then the xy plane to get from the second vector to the third vector, or can we rotate in the xy plane first? thanks\u00a0"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["hw2", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Yongkang Cheng", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk25qpxknv", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Eileen Yang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk8uze41ca", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Ryan Goodfellow", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukl9vtm32fa", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 173, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-05T02:08:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukgl49p220m", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-05T02:17:10Z", "content": "I think you would first rotate in the xz-plane then rotate in the xy-plane as it states in the context of the question above part 1 that "To point the camera in another direction, the camera is given two linear transformations, the first being a rotation in the xz-plane and the second being rotation in the xy-plane."
