You need some composition of the two given rotations, as many as it takes.\u00a0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-05T19:50:19Z", "content": "Part 2 does not ask for a specific order.\u00a0"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lndldvbohtu6s8", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "So would any order would be fine?", "created": "2023-10-05T23:25:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_2", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Order matters when finding theta for different rotations, but you can rotate in different planes in different orders to get to the same spot.", "created": "2023-10-07T01:41:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lm7ukmhsyd2ij", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lnfddod3ufbyr", "updated": "2023-10-07T01:41:45Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 1, "id": "lndt2srofy5rg", "updated": "2023-10-07T01:41:45Z", "config": {"editor": "plain"}}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7uk25qpxknv", "lm7uk8uze41ca", "lm7ukl9vtm32fa"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lnciu83kwqp7kc", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 6, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176021684, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 247, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-05T03:08:14Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lncll6tes921mi", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-05T03:08:14Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llz72s3k38i570", "data": "lnclr93ohm83p0", "to": "lncll6tauxb1mh", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-10-05T03:12:57Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lndld4om31550q", "to": "lncll6tauxb1mh", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-05T19:49:44Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Vector form of a line", "created": "2023-10-05T03:08:14Z", "content": "
Solve for the vector form of a line. With the same\u00a0\ud835\udc65-intercept as [\ud835\udc65,\u00a0\ud835\udc66,\u00a0\ud835\udc67] = [3, 0, 0] +\u00a0\ud835\udc61[4, \u22124, 1] and the same\u00a0\ud835\udc67-intercept as [\ud835\udc65,\u00a0\ud835\udc66,\u00a0\ud835\udc67] = [6, \u22122, \u22123] +\u00a0\ud835\udc61[3, \u22121, \u22122]

How do I find my z-intercept so that I can find the equation of the line?\u00a0

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 110, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-05T03:12:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Hannah Schmidt", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukdf56c21pt", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llz72s3k38i570", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-05T03:12:57Z", "content": "I believe you would set x and y to 0 in the second equation and solve for the parameter \u201ct\u201d. Then, plug t back into the second equation to solve for z which will give your z intercept of (0,0,z)

The equations would look like:\u00a0
For x: 0 = 6 + 3t
For y: 0 = -2 - 1t
For z: z = -3 -2t


"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukdf56c21pt"], "children": [], "id": "lnclr93k6h93oz", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-05T19:49:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-05T19:49:44Z", "content": "$z$ intercept is when the $$x$$ and $$y$$ value are zero, similarly $$x$$ intercept is when the $$y$$ and $$z$$ value are zero.\u00a0"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lndld4okquy50p", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lncll6tauxb1mh", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176022764, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Hi, does anyone know how to do this question?

I first find the degree of rotation by subtracting the angle of B (7pi/19) with A(5pi/19). 

Then I find the dilation scalar, which is the length of A divided by B. (8/5.5) 

And then I multiply the both of them 

which results in:

8/5.5cos2pi/19.      -8/5.5sin2pi/19

8/5.5sin2pi/19.         8/5.5cos2pi/19

But I still got it wrong.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["webwork_and_gateway"], "nr": 270, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-07T14:36:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukjfhgbd29r", "data": "lng528901wj40j", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-07T14:36:40Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lngaa833nxi35c", "to": "lng5288x1n40i", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-07T17:02:51Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukjfhgbd29r", "subject": "WeBWork 3: Problem 4", "created": "2023-10-07T14:36:40Z", "content": "

Hi!

Can anyone explain to me how to decide this matching question?

If I test them out by multiplying each of them with Identity matrix and test the same matrix with a random vector, the conclusion becomes different.

For example: a matrix can have 2 transformations: the result of reflection and rotation, which makes it confusing

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork_and_gateway"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 127, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-07T17:02:51Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-07T17:02:51Z", "content": "The purpose of the question is that you write the standard matrices of the given linear maps yourself by plugging in standard vectors. Every standard matrix corresponds to exactly one linear transformation. Two linear transformations may have the same output for some vectors (ex: reflection w.r.t y-axis and counterclockwise rotation through 180 degrees on $$\vec e_1$$ give the same output) but that doesn't mean they produce the same output for every input.  "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lngaa82yf4g359", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lng5288x1n40i", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176047646, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["tutorials"], "nr": 276, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-07T22:19:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lngll19uhf2fi", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-07T22:19:11Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lngqs5ko3gk1wz", "to": "lngll19rhojfh", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-08T00:44:42Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Tutorial 2 Part 3 of Dev.Question", "created": "2023-10-07T22:19:11Z", "content": "

I was hoping someone could explain how we arrive at a line parallel to Ax=0 that intersects the end of Ax=b (the third developmental question). I understand the first 2 parts but I can't seem to connect it to the diagram. 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "tutorials"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Sunny Wu", "endorser": {"ljajlq9tev95ta": 1690215730, "global": 1693234144}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 107, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-08T00:44:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Zain Glover", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm0p9o3xo7a2jo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-08T00:44:42Z", "content": "

From (1) and (2) you can deduce that the set $$G_b=\{\vec x_1+\vec x_h\:|\: \vec x_h \text{ is a solution to }A\vec x=\vec 0\}$$ is the general solution of $$A\vec x=\vec b$$. Now in part (3), suppose that the general solution to $$A\vec x=0$$, that is $$G_0=\{\vec x\:|\: A\vec x=\vec 0\}$$, is a line. You can see that the vectors in $$G_b$$ are vectors in $$G_0$$ shifter by $$\vec x_1$$. So, geometrically $$G_b$$ is a line shifted by $$\vec x_1$$, which will be a line parallel to the one drawn in the picture, that passes through to tip of $$\vec x_1$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm0p9o3xo7a2jo"], "children": [], "id": "lngqs5klgfg1wy", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["ljrlqru2ii55a3"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lngll19rhojfh", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 3, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176054123, "default_anonymity": "no"}

As I was looking through the Midterm 1 list of definitions document I noticed that there was a definiton for 'image.' I don't recall seeing this in the PCEs, lectures or the textbook. Is this something we need to know for the midterm? Thank you.

\n

\n

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exams", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 167, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-08T03:24:46Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-08T03:24:46Z", "content": "Image is another word for the range of a function or transformation. Understandably the definition makes it look like something entirely different."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lngwi0f4m2k26", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-08T04:42:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-08T04:42:47Z", "content": "Teh concept of image or range was briefly mentioned at the beginning of Post Class Reading 3, simply to differentiate between range and codomain. that is why the definition is included in that Post Class Reading. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 286, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-08T18:24:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lnhsmmjsdxw68p", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-08T18:24:09Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lnidz0wxsd826r", "to": "lnhsmmjq5zx68o", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-09T04:21:40Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Linear combination", "created": "2023-10-08T18:24:09Z", "content": "Can someone explain to me the concept of linear combination I\u2019m having a hard time trying to understand it.\u00a0"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Aqsam Chaudhary", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul1sqfpt3ux", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Tashrifa Muhit", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm6q97pl63md9", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 127, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-09T04:21:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Hannah Schmidt", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukdf56c21pt", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-09T04:21:40Z", "content": "

A linear combination of vectors $$\\vec v_1$$, $$\\vec v_2\\cdots, \\vec v_k$$ is an expression of the form $$c_1\\vec v_1+c_2\\vec v_2+\\cdots c_k\\vec v_k$$. For example $$\\begin{bmatrix}2\\\\3\\end{bmatrix}$$ is a linear combination of $$\\begin{bmatrix} 1\\\\1\\end{bmatrix}$$ and $$\\begin{bmatrix} 0\\\\1\\end{bmatrix}$$ because $$\\begin{bmatrix}2\\\\3\\end{bmatrix}=2\\begin{bmatrix} 1\\\\1\\end{bmatrix}+\\begin{bmatrix} 0\\\\1\\end{bmatrix}$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukdf56c21pt"], "children": [], "id": "lnidz0wsw0126p", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ul1sqfpt3ux", "lm6q97pl63md9"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lnhsmmjq5zx68o", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176064911, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 2, "folders": ["lectures"], "nr": 291, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-08T23:47:53Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llyhj9awro63lb", "data": "lni46y5z2o6mu", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-08T23:47:53Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llyhj9awro63lb", "data": "lni47akqwox7hv", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2023-10-08T23:48:09Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lni4ug4n3e64b5", "to": "lni46y5xikr6mt", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-10-09T00:06:09Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lnj6msl3fdl5oz", "to": "lni46y5xikr6mt", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-09T17:43:58Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llyhj9awro63lb", "subject": "Week 2 PCE: example of using rank function to determine if system has a single solution", "created": "2023-10-08T23:48:09Z", "content": "

In PCE for Week 2 there is a an example on page 7 that reads as follows:

Write a condition on rank of $$A$$ and $$B$$ that is equivalent to saying the corresponding system is consistent with exactly one solution.

My understanding is that the condition will be as follows:

$$\text{Rank}(A)=\text{Rank}(B)=\text{# of rows in $A$}$$

That is, we need both equal ranks for the coefficient matrix $$A$$ and the augmented matrix $$B$$, and we also need them to be equal to the number of rows in either matrix, since we need to ensure there are no free variables. Is this logic correct?

Follow up: is there a better notation to indicate row count in a matrix?

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llyhj9awro63lb", "subject": "Week 2 PCE: example of using rank function to determine if system has a single solution", "created": "2023-10-08T23:47:53Z", "content": "

In PCE for Week 2 there is a an example that reads as follows:

Write a condition on rank of $$A$$ and $$B$$ that is equivalent to saying the corresponding system is consistent with exactly one solution.

My understanding is that the condition will be as follows:

$$\text{Rank}(A)=\text{Rank}(B)=\text{# of rows in $A$}$$

That is, we need both equal ranks for the coefficient matrix $$A$$ and the augmented matrix $$B$$, and we also need them to be equal to the number of rows in either matrix, since we need to ensure there are no free variables. Is this logic correct?

Follow up: is there a better notation to indicate row count in a matrix?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 95, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-09T00:06:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-09T00:06:09Z", "content": "This assumes that the A is an n x n matrix whereby the number of variables is the same as the number of variables, but what if you have a matrix that m < n then it is not even possible for the rank A and B = n. I think a better answer would be that if rank A = m and rank B = m-1."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lni4ug4jqx54b4", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-09T17:43:58Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Boris Potapov", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "llyhj9awro63lb", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-09T17:43:58Z", "content": "

For the system to be consistent, you need the rank of the coefficient and augmented matrix to be the same. So your logic id great here. 

For the system to have no free variable you need every COLUMN of the coefficient matrix to be a pivot column. In other words, you need the rank of the coefficient matrix to be equal to the number of its columns (and not rows).

Your notation for # of rows is fine. If you indicate earlier that $$A_{n\times m}$$, then # of rows   is $$n$$. 
 

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["llyhj9awro63lb"], "children": [], "id": "lnj6msl0jzw5oy", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lni46y5xikr6mt", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176070312, "default_anonymity": "no"}

vector times Matrix\u00a0
Matrix times Matrix

But did we learn vector times vector?\u00a0
"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["logistics", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 97, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-09T01:44:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukgl49p220m", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-09T01:44:50Z", "content": "There\u2019s two times of vector multiplication. For products and cross products. Dot products give us a scalar. Cross products give us a vector which is perpendicular to the two vectors being multiplied."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lni8dcrbi4d7e2", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "but we did not learn dot prodict", "created": "2023-10-09T01:45:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Dot product was brought up several times during the course content

", "created": "2023-10-09T01:46:59Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lcovl1vrqk86bx", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lni8g44iq5t52s", "updated": "2023-10-09T01:47:17Z", "config": {}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "i mean cross product sorry\u00a0", "created": "2023-10-09T01:47:30Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lni8gs9surc6jh", "updated": "2023-10-09T01:47:30Z", "config": {}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 1, "id": "lni8ekjm4gi1y4", "updated": "2023-10-09T01:47:30Z", "config": {}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-09T04:30:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-09T04:30:45Z", "content": "In general, there is no vector times vector. There is an operation for vectors in $$\\mathbb R^3$$ that takes in two vectors and generates a third called cross product. It is not accurate to think of cross-product as vector multiplication as it is not generalizable to all vectors.\u00a0 We have not talked about cross product in the course, you instructor may have covered in during week 1.\u00a0"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lnieapqw35k3p8", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lni8bjvqtjn3a6", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176072469, "default_anonymity": "no"}

You can prove that the statement in question 3 is true by putting the planes into a matrix and solving RREF. You will find that the bottom plane cancels out, as does any linear combination in a matrix, which leaves one free variable for a line.

For question 4, like the solution says, pretty much any combo of planes is guaranteed to intersect at exactly one point if none of the planes are parallel, equal, or a linear combination, which potentially lead to other cases.

I found WebWork 2 questions 5-7 useful, as it helps you visualize what these planes look like and how they intersect.

To find the standard matrix of any linear transformation, you should find the output of the standard vectors. As for projection, in Post Class Readings of week 3 you deduced a formula that is true for projection onto any line in $$\mathbb R^n$$. Given a vector in $$\vec u\in \mathbb R^n$$, then 

$$ proj_{\vec u}\vec x=\frac{\vec x\cdot \vec u}{\vec u\cdot \vec u}\vec u$$

for all vectors $$\vec x$$ in $$\mathbb R^n$$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures"], "nr": 301, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-09T04:31:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ul026hxa3os", "data": "lniebhhy23w67v", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-09T04:31:21Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "data": "lniub5ty60m14r", "to": "lniebhhvd6i67u", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-10-09T11:59:00Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lniebhhvd6i67u", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-10-09T14:49:54Z", "cid": "lnj0ey5yn8840f", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lnj5fcg2959498", "to": "lniebhhvd6i67u", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-09T17:10:11Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lnj5gzo9pws7q", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2023-10-09T17:11:27Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ul026hxa3os", "subject": "Is the Zero vector parallel to all vectors?", "created": "2023-10-09T04:31:21Z", "content": "If the definition of parallel vectors is that v = kw where k is a Real Number, then wouldn’t having k = 0 mean that [0,0] = kw, making the zero vector parallel to all vectors? By definition, the zero vector is also orthogonal to all vectors.

If v is parallel to a and a is parallel to w,  it follows that v is parallel to w. However, if a = [0,0] and [0,0] is parallel to all vectors, wouldn’t this imply that all vectors are parallel to each other? Obviously this can’t be the case.

Is there any restriction on k in the definition of parallel vectors? Would appreciate any clarification.
"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 146, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-09T11:59:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-09T11:59:00Z", "content": "

In Prof. Shai Cohen's class, he mentioned that the zero vector does not have direction, with the justification that if you set it orthogonal to one vector, $$\overrightarrow a$$, for example, you could then set it parallel to $$\overrightarrow b$$ or something like that, then you could claim $$\overrightarrow a⊥\overrightarrow b$$ although it could be false. The example you provided also makes it clear why the zero vector should not have direction.

Also, he provided a distinction between perpendicular and orthogonal, stating that perpendicular would be dot product = 0 but the vectors involved should not be 0 vectors, but orthogonal vectors have a dot product equal to 0 but can involve zero vectors.

However, I'm not too sure for parallel lines as the condition is that the vectors should be scalar multiples, where internet sources point out that the zero vector is a scalar multiple of any other vector

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lniub5tv2pp14q", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Zero vector is orthogonal to all vectors, but not parallel. I'm pretty sure that we defined k as nonzero, but you'd have to double check. ", "created": "2023-10-09T14:49:54Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lnj0ey5yn8840f", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2023-10-09T14:50:12Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-09T17:10:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Petercho", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l79f0nd0qdt5x", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-09T17:11:27Z", "content": "This is a very good question and the answer is a matter of convention (definition). Our textbook (Appendix A) defined two vectors to be parallel if one is the multiple of the other. Based on this definition, $$\vec 0$$ is parallel to all other vectors (Example 4 Appendix A). Another (perhaps more common) definition of parallel vectors is " two vectors are parallel if they are multiple of one another". Based on this definition $$\vec 0$$ is not parallel to other vectors. 

Now, the property you mentioned, called transitivity property, is a required property for a relation (in this instance being parallel is a relation between two vectors) to be an equivalency relation. Based on our definition, being parallel is not transitive, and hence not an equivalence relation. If one needs this relation to be transitive (there are many reasons why one might want this, but none of them apply to this course) then the second definition is teh one to go with."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-09T17:10:11Z", "content": "This is a very good question and the answer is a matter of convention (definition). Our textbook (Appendix A) defined two vectors to be parallel if one is the multiple of the other. Based on this definition, $$\vec 0$$ is parallel to all other vectors (Example 4 Appendix A). Another (perhaps more common) definition of parallel vectors is " two vectors are parallel if they are multiple of one another". Based on this definition $$\vec 0$$ is not parallel to other vectors. 

Now, the property you mentioned, called transitivity property, is the required property for a relation (in this instance being parallel is a relation between two vectors) to be an equivalency relation. Based on our definition, being parallel is not transitive, and hence not an equivalence relation. If one needs this relation to be transitive (there are many reasons why one might want this, but none of them apply to this course) then the second definition is teh one to go with. "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["l79f0nd0qdt5x"], "children": [], "id": "lnj5fcg0q2e497", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lniebhhvd6i67u", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176081112, "default_anonymity": "no"}

The question asks for the intersection of A and B, as indicated by the upside-down U.
To find this, we can plug the two plane equations into an augmented matrix to solve for the solution of the system, which will give us an RREF matrix with the z variable being the free variable; this means that the solution is a line.

We can then let z = t, so that we can get the vector equation of the line: L = (2, 3/2, 0) + (-3, 1/2, 1)*t, where t is a real number.

Out of the three given options, only one involves a line, but it has a direction vector [-10, 1, 2]; that option isn't correct because its direction vector isn't collinear (scalable) with our direction vector [-3, 1/2, 1]. Additionally, the point given in Option #3 isn't the same as the one we get (2, 3/2, 0).

Therefore, the correct option is "None of the above". If I made a calculation mistake, please edit this.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk2nchjopf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-09T16:44:47Z", "content": "

Consider the -u -2v +w. What are the coefficients? 

These are <-1, -2, 1> . That is where they are coming from. Try not looking at the solution, you can verify it is true by multiplying the first column (u) by -1, the second (v) by -2, and the third (w) by 1, and add the result (as we are used to computing). The result is indeed the vector x (or the 4th column), therefore we can say it's true.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 315, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-09T18:55:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lnj96fo0qaf3eg", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-09T18:55:13Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jxvyiqnmf22y1", "data": "lnja8uoms6e2j2", "to": "lnj96fny9cx3ef", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-09T19:25:06Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Rotations by theta in R2", "created": "2023-10-09T18:55:13Z", "content": "

Question,

\n

When we're rotating in R2, does positive theta represent a counterclockwise rotation by theta, and negative theta represent a clockwise rotation by theta?

I believe the best way to solve this question would be to treat it as a set of equations.

You have

(a b)   (-2)     ( 5)

(c d) x (-1) = (-5)

(a b)   (6)     (-11)

(c d) x (7) = ( 27)

You can expand these into a set of 4 equations with 4 unknowns. Then solve for a, b, c, and d.

If a transformation is injective, it maps every vector input to a unique vector output. That is, you can be sure that if $$T(\overrightarrow{v})=T(\overrightarrow{w})$$ then $$\overrightarrow{v} = \overrightarrow{w}$$. In words, you can be sure that if two transformed vectors are the same, then their inputs are the same. 

Now, the question asks if two different inputs can yield the same output. In terms of injectivity, it is essentially asking if N is injective or not. If N is not injective, then it would be possible for your brain to perceive two different colors as the same. If N is injective, then it would not be possible. To determine injectivity, you should look for a unique solution, which can be done by taking $$rref(N)$$. In this case, $$rref(N)$$ has a rank of 3, or has a pivot in every column, meaning it is consistent with a unique solution, thus it is injective, so the above scenario would be impossible. On the contrary, if the rank was only 2, then if N was consistent, it would be possible for two different colors to be perceived as the same color since there is no unique solution.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exams"], "nr": 331, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-10T00:35:22Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lnjlbvaxg5e6q6", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-10T00:35:22Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lnjli9bhitk4a2", "to": "lnjlbvaudaa6q4", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-10T00:40:20Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "How to prove something", "created": "2023-10-10T00:35:22Z", "content": "

Hello,

\n

If a question asks us to prove something that is general like a = 4t where we aren't given any exact values, would we be able to consider it proven if we show one or two examples where what we are trying to prove are true?\u00a0

\n

Thank you.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exams", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Javeria Rashid", "endorser": {"ljajlq9tev95ta": 1689021907, "global": 1691952516}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljqmhr1vwkc1b0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 116, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-10T00:40:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Wareesha Ahsan Qureshi", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukfk6s2j1x2", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-10T00:40:20Z", "content": "We have not taught you how to prove mathematical statements, and will not ask you to do so. Hello, I’m not quite understanding why this is the correct answer (refer to image). I keep getting that answer but with opposite signs

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Practice Midterm question 2a", "created": "2023-10-10T02:39:33Z", "content": "Hello, I’m not quite understanding why this is the answer (refer to image) is correct. I keep getting that answer but with opposite signs 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exams", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 133, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-10T02:49:59Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nora Liu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "llz72s3k38i570", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-10T02:53:08Z", "content": "Look at it by using the vectors v1,v2,v3 as the transformed standard vectors (e1,e2,e3). Now reflect the standard vectors on the xy plane. Then record your new transformed vectors as v1,v2,v3 (the columns of A). For this question, it definitely helps to draw it out. Make sure ur axes follow the right hand rule to ensure you’ve placed the positive direction in the correct place when creating your diagram."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukdddsph1po", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-10T02:49:59Z", "content": "Not sure if this makes sense but think back to a reflection of a vector with respect to the y-axis in a 2D plane. The y component stays the same while the x component switches signs. It’s the same in 3D. If you have a table for example, and say that you are reflecting a vase on that table with respect to the table. Then, that vase would be on that same position on the table, except flipped and under the table. 

It’s the same idea with this question. You are reflecting with respect to the xy-plane, so the x’s and y’s stay the same while the z component is flipped. Let me know if this works for you!
"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["llz72s3k38i570"], "children": [], "id": "lnjq4z0onqd4b5", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lnjprk00bm13am", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1, "editor": "rte"}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176121053, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures"], "nr": 365, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-14T01:08:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lnpc9lsbf8o6a6", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-14T01:08:17Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lnsexnjz1nk2nq", "to": "lnpc9ls9xj26a5", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-16T04:46:17Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "How to prove Det(A) = Det(A^T)", "created": "2023-10-14T01:08:17Z", "content": "Hello. Thank you ."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 114, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-16T04:46:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-16T04:46:17Z", "content": "One way to see why $$A$$ and $$A^T$$ have the same determinant is through the cofactor expaction formula. For part (a), we are looking for estimates - take the diagram and use it to get a rough sense of the masses.\u00a0 Think of the limbs as roughly cylindrical, the head as a sphere, and the torso as a prism, get an idea of their relative size, and do some arithmetic.\u00a0

\n

\n

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures"], "nr": 371, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-15T01:20:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lnqs58oelc0jf", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-15T01:20:34Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "hlnuq2z6msj5y1", "data": "lnrqafpv66n7d1", "to": "lnqs58oa1k2je", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-15T17:16:23Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "LEC0106 - Placeholder Symbol", "created": "2023-10-15T01:20:34Z", "content": "

During the afternoon lecture on 13 oct. 2023, Prof. Cohen used the "~" symbol to replace an irrelevant expression in a computation (specifically the non-zero factor in a multiplication of the form $$0\cdot x$$). He introduced this symbol as "blah" in what I presume was a statement made in jest (if I recall correctly he said that « ...the technical term for this is blah. »).

While I imagine this is not actually permissible in proper mathematical work, I am curious if there is a proper symbol that acts as a placeholder in math. Specifically, does there exist a symbol which generally represents an irrelevant quantity?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Toon Craps", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Deena Abrari", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukrjw9d22xr", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Tashrifa Muhit", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm6q97pl63md9", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 125, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-15T17:16:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Chris Mak", "endorser": {"llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1695815518}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Deena Abrari", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukrjw9d22xr", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "hlnuq2z6msj5y1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-15T17:16:23Z", "content": "

I have never tried to submit a mathematics paper that uses the blah symbol, so I am not certain that it is not allowed.

There is no official symbol to indicate an irrelevant portion of a line of mathematics, but you will sometimes see different attempts at it.

"uid": "hlnuq2z6msj5y1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-20T01:36:37Z", "content": "

That does seem to be an issue.  I will look into it and reply here later, hopefully tonight.  I complained to my sister, the architect, about the source and she just told me to complain to the author.  He passed away in the 90's.

For the estimates, please see @366.

-------

Okay. So, I printed up the page at 150% sizing in order to carefully measure the distances and try to understand what is going on - where is the scale of the diagram wrong?

Then, I realized that it does not matter. The outer, dashed lines do not represent anything to do with the stance of the person - the statics of the position are determined by the crutches, not by the dashed lines.  I looked further down and found that the lines represent how far out the crutches are swung as a person takes a step, which is excellent for us to know in general, but the ramp in Hart House is wide enough that it does not matter.

So, the answer is that you can freely ignore B (and, therefore, E).  They are not relevant to the question we are asking.

Measuring the height and length A of the left figure, the person is around 202 cm tall. This is inconsistent with the answer we found in part (a).

Solutions include:

1. Ignore this inconsistency and arrive at inconsistent results

2. Measure the height of the figure and use 202cm as height

3. Take numbers below as a scale and "shrink" the figure's labels until consistent with result from part (a).

As @384 pointed out, the numbers themselves are not consistent with the scale of the figure. This makes both solutions 2. and 3. require additional information on which scale we should do calculations on. (unmentioned problems also occur on parts (d) and (e) where it is unclear which body parts would move as the person is placed upon the ramp, or even if the person is facing up or down the ramp!!)

While I understand the intent that this question is supposed to emulate the use of linear algebra within an actual project (our own Hart House theater project no less), and some arbitration (about the measurements and abstractions of body parts) on our parts may even be intended (to capture the complexity of working with different pieces of data), there is too much inconsistency between obtained pieces of data to make the question satisfy its role as a marked problem in a problem set. It places unnecessary burden on all of TAs (to check for vastly different but all correct answers without a set rubric), students (to understand the intent of the question and manage these inconsistencies, and professors (to answer these endless questions about which interpretation is correct).

I advocate for the removal of this question from being weighed on the final mark-scheme, or a modified, more consistent version be made to prevent students from having to look for scattered pieces of information around Piazza.

Thank you!

Hello,

How would we check if T is injective and/or surjective? 

As well as that, is it possible to find the kernel of T?

Thank you

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["hw3", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Tashrifa Muhit", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm6q97pl63md9", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Justin Altimari", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukzt7hwa3o3", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 221, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-20T04:37:30Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-20T04:37:30Z", "content": "There are multiple approaches. Hello,

\n

\n

Thank you.

Hi, 

When justifying whether or not T is linear, would we have to expand the determinant to show (whether or not) the linearity property holds, or does it suffice to write Det[v, w, x+y] = Det [v, w, x] + Det [v, w, y] holds by definition of linearity of columns? 

Thanks

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Q3 part 3b justification", "created": "2023-10-20T16:39:10Z", "content": "

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures"], "nr": 420, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-20T22:26:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lnz6kaz5bfe1t1", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-20T22:26:20Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lnzgsi6o8h420s", "to": "lnz6kaz2pm51sz", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-21T03:12:39Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lnzgtj56exf3sk", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2023-10-21T03:13:27Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Redundant Column Vector Clarification", "created": "2023-10-20T22:26:20Z", "content": "

In today's lecture, we deduced that v1 and v2 are the basis of the im(T), and that v3 and v4 are redundant since you can write them in terms of v1 and v2. But I think it is possible to write v1 in terms of v2, v3, and v4 (v1 = v2 - v3 - v4). Would this not make v1 also redundant or is there another reason, maybe in relation to it being a pivot column, and a basic variable, not free?

\n

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Jacky Zhao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lju72nwqwxz3ci", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 158, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-21T03:12:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mazen Ismail", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukdbn6w71pk", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-21T03:13:27Z", "content": "You are right. Being redundant is not an intrinsic property of a vector. Indeed, we are able to create another basis for $$im(T)$$ that does not contain $$\\vec v_1$$. To keep our work systematic, however, we consider an order for the vectors, and a vector would be redundant if it could be written as a linear combination of vectors showing up before it. Our RREF allows us to easily identify these vectors. Going with this order, we decide to keep $$\\vec v_1$$, and $$\\vec v_2$$ as they are not linear combinations of vectors before them, and throw away $$\\vec v_3$$, and $$\\vec v_4$$. Now if you change the order of the vectors, this system tells you to keep some other vectors. What always remains the same is the number of vectors you end up keeping/throwing away."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-21T03:12:39Z", "content": "You are right. Being redundant is not an intrinsic property of a vector. Indeed, we are able to create another basis for $$im(T)$$ that does not contain $$\\vec v_1$$. To keep our work systematic, however, we consider an order for the vectors, and a vector would be redundant if it could be written as vectors showing up before it. Our RREF allows us to easily identify these vectors. Going with this order, we decide to keep $$\\vec v_1$$, and $$\\vec v_2$$ as they are not linear combinations of vectors before them, and throw away $$\\vec v_3$$, and $$\\vec v_4$$. Now if you change the order of the vectors, this system tells you to keep some other vectors. What always remains the same is the number of vectors you end up keeping/throwing away.\u00a0"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukdbn6w71pk"], "children": [], "id": "lnzgsi6lmzf20r", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lju72nwqwxz3ci"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lnz6kaz2pm51sz", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176209566, "default_anonymity": "no"}

As for where exactly that point is situated you have options. Each option gives you an estimate, some estimates will be less accurate than others and will have higher risk factors. You can model the body part as a cube, then distribute the weight evenly to the vertices of the curve, and use the center of the mass formula (from HW1) to determine the center of the mass of that part, OR for a course estimate, you can allocate the mass to teh geometrical center of that body part. Note that this problem is open-ended, the more details you work out the more accurate of an estimate you get and the more safe and applicable your final analysis will be. "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukwctwd63cu", "lm7uklh38no2ft", "lm7uk96a8bm1dp", "lm7ukrjw9d22xr"], "children": [], "id": "lo05lqkuzw76jr", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ukblbjsy1ku", "lm7uklh38no2ft", "lm6q97pl63md9"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lnzcjm50sm66wn", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176212806, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Hello,

For this question, are there multiple right answers? Or is there just one right answer that we are working towards? Also, is it important to assume that R is a right angle triangle or is it fine if we don't do that? Would assuming that its a right angle triangle make solving the question easier?

Thank you.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["hw3", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Chizaram Amobi-Oleka", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljltcjb8xa5408", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 245, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-21T01:57:06Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Wareesha Ahsan Qureshi", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukfk6s2j1x2", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llz72s3k38i570", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-21T01:57:55Z", "content": "I’m pretty sure there are multiple rights answers for question 1 depending on which numbers you choose. Also, R must be a right triangle because the sign lengths satisfy 5^2 = 4^2 + 3^2"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llz72s3k38i570", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-21T01:57:06Z", "content": "Yes there are multiple rights answers for question 1. Also, R must be a right triangle because the sign lengths satisfy 5^2 = 4^2 + 3^2"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukfk6s2j1x2"], "children": [], "id": "lnze3ckid8n1lv", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-21T02:59:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nithura Thevarajah", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk96a8bm1dp", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-21T02:59:25Z", "content": "

1) Although you have a lot of choices on how to position $$R$$ in your coordinate system, and which right angle triangle you choose to transform into, the area of the largest ellipse inside $$R$$ is always the same.  

2) $$R$$ being right-angled is not an assumption. The right angle is dictated by the length of the sides, says Pythagoras.

For problem 3 part b), the question says to point the x-axis "toward the person". Does this mean point it vertically upward? No, because the z-axis is pointing vertically upward. So does it mean to point it into the page? But this doesn't point the x-axis toward the person. Or is it saying to point it diagonally towards the person on the left side of the page? Thank you

Hi, I am confused about how we can estimate the dimensions of the legs, torso, arms and head based on the diagram.\u00a0

\n

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["hw3"], "nr": 445, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-22T00:31:05Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lo0qgkob9rs1a0", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-22T00:31:05Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "hlnuq2z6msj5y1", "data": "lo1lewc4dyb6mu", "to": "lo0qgko8uln19z", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-22T14:57:35Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "rear leg overlap", "created": "2023-10-22T00:31:05Z", "content": "For q3 pt(b) of assignment 3, when it says both legs are situated where the rear leg is, does that mean both legs are behind the body but not necessarily overlapping one another, or that the right leg essentially doubles in mass and the left leg disappears?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["hw3", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 138, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-22T14:57:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "hlnuq2z6msj5y1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-22T14:57:35Z", "content": "

Almost.\u00a0 Just imagine that the two legs are held straight and in the direction of the rear leg that is shown.\u00a0 It's not one extra-heavy leg, but two parallel legs.

\n

\n

The advice I gave in my office hours was that you should picture your approximation of the figure.\u00a0 If it makes you want to run away in horror, then there is something wrong.\u00a0 It should just look like a very blocky person.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["hw3"], "nr": 446, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-22T01:16:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lo0s39hytid1sx", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-22T01:16:43Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "hlnuq2z6msj5y1", "data": "lo1lbkdeo4d2ev", "to": "lo0s39hvvph1sw", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-22T14:54:59Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "HW 3 Question 3", "created": "2023-10-22T01:16:43Z", "content": "Are we allowed to use a calculator for the whole question or just for finding the average measurements?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["hw3", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 121, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-22T14:54:59Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "hlnuq2z6msj5y1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-22T14:54:59Z", "content": "The best approach here is to use the calculator minimally.\u00a0 You will need it on occasion, but (for example) stick to sines and cosines until a final step where you throw everything on to a calculator to get a 2- or 3-digit approximation."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lo1lbkdbfth2eu", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lo0s39hvvph1sw", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176237649, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["hw3"], "nr": 447, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-22T01:46:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lo0t5pvnqat5kb", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-22T01:46:37Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kf2z2j444pg31s", "data": "lo0vfd8la927n5", "to": "lo0t5pvis3d5ka", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-22T02:50:07Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "HW3 Problem 2 Question 3 Part d", "created": "2023-10-22T01:46:37Z", "content": "What would be the span of one vector with only one dimension?? Like for example if i had [5], would the span of that just be the one point at x=5?\u00a0"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["hw3", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Audrik Choudhury", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukn2d4i02kz", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 121, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-22T02:50:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Angelina Zhu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukgfqdy6208", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kf2z2j444pg31s", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-22T02:50:07Z", "content": "Consider that the span of a set can be equivalently stated as the set of all linear combinations of the vectors within that set. So, the span of the set $$\\{5\\}$$ is in fact all of the reals! {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exams"], "nr": 458, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-23T22:21:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lo3gpqh1hk35he", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-23T22:21:35Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "data": "lo3gytu07ax7m3", "to": "lo3gpqgxun35hd", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-23T22:28:39Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Regrade Request for Midterm I", "created": "2023-10-23T22:21:35Z", "content": "

Hello, 

How can I make a regrade request on Gradescope for the Midterm I test? I am wondering if there was an error in the grading and would like to request a regrade for the particular question, but there seems to be no "Regrade Request" button. Sorry again, and thank you for the help. Screenshot_2023-10-23_181958.png

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exams", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 124, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-23T22:28:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Cheraldine", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lk2hzunvawj3nc", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-23T22:28:39Z", "content": "

Quoted from the most recent weekly update:

If you think your grade for a particular question doesn't follow the rubric, you can request a regrade. The regrade request will open Tuesday (Oct 24th) morning and stay for 4 days. For your regrade request to be considered you should 1) clearly explain why you think the rubric item you are assigned does not reflect your work 2) you should clearly and explicitly refer to the rubric and the solutions. Simply saying "I don't think my grade is fair" is not sufficient grounds for a regrade. 3) any regrade request may lead to a grade higher, lower, or equal to the original one.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["webwork_and_gateway"], "nr": 462, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-24T03:22:04Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lo3rg5p022n38i", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-24T03:22:04Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lo4fny9oc2fr0", "to": "lo3rg5oxj0z38h", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-24T14:39:58Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Linearly independent vectors in a set", "created": "2023-10-24T03:22:04Z", "content": "

Hello,

\n

If we are given a set of 4 vectors that span R^4, how would we determine which of the given vectors are linearly dependent? If we were to row reduce the matrix whose columns are the vectors, how would we tell which of the vectors is linearly independent and which ones are linearly dependent?

\n

Thank you.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork_and_gateway"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Sunny Wu", "endorser": {"ljajlq9tev95ta": 1690215730, "global": 1693234144}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 106, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-24T14:39:58Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-24T14:39:58Z", "content": ""Linearly independent and dependent" is a term used for a collection of vectors. We can not say a single vector inside a larger collection is linearly dependent or independent. Any set that contains a single nonzero vector is linearly independent.\u00a0

What you want to ask is how do I know which vectors are redundant and I can remove them from the collection without changing the span of the collection. You can so that by creating a matrix A whose columns are your vectors and by finding a nontrivial vector in the kernel of A. Any such vector gives you a nontrivial linear relation which you can use to write one of your vectors as a lc of the rest, and the repeat the process.\u00a0

If you have 4 vectors that span $$\\mathbb R^4$$, because you know the dimension of the space, and you have the right number of vectors, your vectors have to be linearly independent.\u00a0"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lo4fny9kqjyqz", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["ljrlqru2ii55a3"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lo3rg5oxj0z38h", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176254912, "default_anonymity": "no"}

How do I find the vectors that span a image given a matrix?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 110, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-24T23:07:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Hannah Kendler", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukk5buf82bu", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jqlesycsafrbh", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-24T23:49:39Z", "content": "

Firstly, what is the image of a matrix? The matrix you have learned is a linear transformation. The image of a transformation $$T$$ that maps $$x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$$ to $$y \in \mathbb{R}^{m}$$ would be the set of all outputs $$y \in \mathbb{R}^{m}$$, given the set of all inputs in $$x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$$, that this transformation can produce. 

In simpler terms if you had a matrix such that:

$$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}$$$$\begin{bmatrix} x_{1} \\ x_{2}  \\ x_{3}  \\ \end{bmatrix}$$ = $$\begin{bmatrix} y_{1} \\ y_{2}  \\ y_{3}  \\ \end{bmatrix}$$

then when you give it distinct inputs with distinct {$$x_{1}$$,$$x_{2}$$,$$x_{3}$$} values, you will get distinct outputs with distinct {$$y_{1}$$,$$y_{2}$$,$$y_{3}$$} values, which in the case of the identity matrix given above are the same as the input. So, if you give it as input all of the vectors in $$ \mathbb{R}^{3}$$ you would get all of $$ \mathbb{R}^{3}$$. 

Now in terms of notation, we refer to the set of outputs as the im$$(T)$$ or the im$$(A)$$ for a given matrix A. In the example provided above the output can be presented as: 

$$im$$(T)$$  =  $$span($$\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0  \\ 0 \end{bmatrix},\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1  \\ 0 \end{bmatrix},\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0  \\ 1 \end{bmatrix})$$.

This means that:

$$im$$(T)$$  =  x_{1}$$$$\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0  \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} + $$$$x_{2}$$$$\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1  \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} + $$$$x_{3}$$$$\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0  \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$$

The above equation holds for $$x_{1}$$, $$x_{2}$$, $$x_{3}$$ having all the possible values, not for specific values.

Also what is the difference between the basis of an image and the basis of the kernel?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "practicals", "student", "tutorials", "webwork_and_gateway"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Justin Altimari", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukzt7hwa3o3", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 120, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-25T19:03:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Justin Altimari", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukzt7hwa3o3", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jqlesycsafrbh", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-25T19:03:26Z", "content": "

Great question!

A matrix you have learned is one form to represent a linear transformation or a map, of a vector $$\vec{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{m}$$ to a vector $$\vec{y} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$$; or to say $$T(\vec{x}) = \vec{y}$$.

So far so good, we pick vectors in $$\mathbb{R}^{m}$$ and map them to vectors in $$\mathbb{R}^n$$. But let's suppose m>n, that means that if you "count" the vectors belonging to $$\mathbb{R}^{m}$$ there are more of them than there are vectors in $$\mathbb{R}^{n}$$, because we assume m>n and thus $$\mathbb{R}^{m}$$ is of a higher dimension than $$\mathbb{R}^{n}$$. One would panic in such a case! But rest assured, those "extra" vectors are actually mapped to the black hole of linear algebra, the zero vector $$\vec{0} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$$. By this reasoning we can resolve this ambiguity by defining two subspaces of interest to us: the image and the kernel of a transformation T or a matrix A, or im(A) and ker(A). 

Image of A, im(A), is the set of all vectors that a transformation defined by a matrix A can produce. So, for example if you had a matrix A such that: 

$$A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0\\ 0 & 1 & 0\\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$$ and $$\vec{y} = A\vec{x} :\vec{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}$$

Then, for $$\vec{x}$$ defined as $$\begin{bmatrix} x_{1}\\ x_{2}\\ x_{3} \end{bmatrix}$$ the output $$\vec{y}$$ will be $$\begin{bmatrix} x_{1}\\ x_{2}\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$$. 

So we can see that even though $$\vec{y}$$ is an element of $$\mathbb{R}^{m}$$ it is actually a 2 dimensional object. We say that the dimension of the image is 2. 

The kernel on the other hand is the set of all input vectors $$\vec{x}$$ that give an input of $$\vec{0}$$. In this case any vector $$\vec{x}$$ of the form $$\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0\\ s \end{bmatrix}$$, where s is a random variable, will give an output of $$\vec{0}$$. That is easy to verify by just multiplying this general vector by the matrix A given above. Even though the kernel is an element of $$\mathbb{R}^{m}$$ it forms a subspace of dimension 1, a line, so we say that the dimension of the kernel is 1. 

From this example you can see that you can find the dimension of the image and the kernel of a square matrix by analyzing the matrix in its reduced row echelon form. Where the number of free variables will give you the dimension of the kernel and the number of leading variables will give you the dimension of the image. 

For more information on representing the answer in terms of basis vectors and span you can look at my previous answer @467.

"data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-26T05:41:14Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-26T05:41:14Z", "content": "

I think they found his two matrices by inspection, but if you want an algorithm, you can use the following one. Define the matrix $$T_{BC}$$ as $$\begin{bmatrix} \overrightarrow{b_1} & \overrightarrow{b_2} \end{bmatrix}$$ increased with $$\begin{bmatrix} \overrightarrow{c_1} & \overrightarrow{c_2} \end{bmatrix}$$. Use the Gauss-Jordan reduction algorithm to reduce the left-hand side to the identity matrix, then the right-hand side columns will be the vectors $$\left[\overrightarrow{b_1}\right]_C$$ and $$\left[\overrightarrow{b_2}\right]_C$$.

(It's late and I can't be bothered to check the translation so if anything doesn't make sense just yell at me. Here's the original text:

Je pense qu'ils l'ont trouvé ses deux matrices par inspection, mais si tu veux un algorithme, tu peux utiliser celle suivant. Définis la matrice $$T_{BC}$$ comme $$\begin{bmatrix} \overrightarrow{b_1} & \overrightarrow{b_2} \end{bmatrix}$$ augmenté avec $$\begin{bmatrix} \overrightarrow{c_1} & \overrightarrow{c_2} \end{bmatrix}$$. Utilise l'algorithme réduction Gauss-Jordan pour réduire le côté gauche à la matrice d'identité, puis les colonnes du côté droite seront les vecteurs $$\left[\overrightarrow{b_1}\right]_C$$ et $$\left[\overrightarrow{b_2}\right]_C$$.)

This concepts can get a bit convoluted so let's break up this problem a little bit, some of this is a repetition of the PCE, so fill free to refer to the PCE if there are parts you don't understand or post another question asking for more details. 

Firstly if you refer a bit back in the PCE, "P" is a subspace of $$\mathbb{R}^{3}$$ defined by the equation $$x+y+z=0$$. This particular subspace is plane, which means it can be defined as the span of any two linearly independent vectors that lie in that plane. For the example, those can be the vectors that form the basis of $$\mathcal{B}$$ or the vectors that form the basis of $$\mathcal{C}$$. So, both those pairs of vectors can be used to define the subspace P. 

Now, when we talk about bases, we usually use them in the context of coordinates. In other words, we can describe points in space, in terms of different vectors other than the unit vectors of $$\vec{e}$$ that we are used to. In this example we can write vector $$\vec{v}$$ such that:

$$\vec{v} = 1*\vec{b}_{1} + 1*\vec{b}_{2}$$, where $$\vec{v}$$ = $$\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$$ = $$1*$$$$\begin{bmatrix} -1\\ -1\\ 2 \end{bmatrix}$$ + $$1*$$$$\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$$

So, $$\begin{bmatrix} \vec{v}\end{bmatrix}_{\mathcal{B}}$$ = $$\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$$

That saves space when we write stuff, both in our notebook pages and in our computer memories. If you think about the example above you can express a point with two numbers instead of 3. One can extend this to higher dimensional spaces, think of a long excel spreadsheet with many numbers in it. That can be one application though not the only one.

We are all good in terms of expressing $$\vec{v}$$ in terms of basis $$\mathcal{B}$$, or even the basis $$\mathcal{C}$$, it's the same idea. But how can we finesse linear algebra and jump straight from the coordinates defined with basis $$\mathcal{B}$$ to coordinates defined with basis $$\mathcal{C}$$.

If you try to represent the first vector in the basis of $$\mathcal{B}$$ in terms of the basis of $$\mathcal{C}$$ you get this: 

$$\vec{b}_{1} = \begin{bmatrix} -1\\-1\\2 \end{bmatrix} = s_{11}* \vec{u}_{1} + s_{21}*\vec{u}_{2} = s_{11}* \begin{bmatrix} -2\\-2\\4 \end{bmatrix} + s_{21}*\begin{bmatrix} 0\\1\\-1 \end{bmatrix} $$

From the above equation one can see by inspection or solve to find that $$s_{11} = \frac{1}{2}$$ and $$s_{21} = 0$$. 

If you try to represent the second vector in the basis of $$\mathcal{B}$$ in terms of the basis of $$\mathcal{C}$$ you get this: 

$$\vec{b}_{2} = \begin{bmatrix} 1\\-1\\0 \end{bmatrix} = s_{12}* \vec{u}_{1} + s_{22}*\vec{u}_{2} = s_{12}* \begin{bmatrix} -2\\-2\\4 \end{bmatrix} + s_{22}*\begin{bmatrix} 0\\1\\-1 \end{bmatrix} $$

From the above equation one can see by inspection or solve to find that $$s_{12} = -\frac{1}{2}$$ and $$s_{22} = -2$$. 

That transformation turns out to be linear and it can be represented by a matrix. Because in this case you go from a representation with 2 coordinates to a representation with 2 coordinates, you kind of know this has to be a 2 by 2 matrix, just based on the matrix operations required and how matrix operations work. 

So, we define a matrix $$S_{B \rightarrow C}$$ such that: 

$$S_{B \rightarrow C} = \begin{bmatrix} s_{11} & s_{12} \\ s_{21} & s_{22} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{2} &  -\frac{1}{2}\\0  & -2 \end{bmatrix}$$

So, both those pairs of vectors can be used to define the subspace P. 

Now, when we talk about bases, we usually use them in the context of coordinates. In other words we can describe points in terms of different vectors other than the unit vectors of $$\vec{e}$$ that we are used to. In this example we can write vector $$\vec{v}$$ such that:

$$\vec{v} = 1*\vec{b}_{1} + 1*\vec{b}_{2}$$, such that $$\vec{v}$$ = $$\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$$ = $$1*$$$$\begin{bmatrix} -1\\ -1\\ 2 \end{bmatrix}$$ + $$1*$$$$\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$$

So, $$\begin{bmatrix} \vec{v}\end{bmatrix}_{\mathcal{B}}$$ = $$\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$$

That saves space when we write stuff, both in our notebook pages and in our computer memories. If you think about the example above you can express a point with two numbers instead of 3. One can extend this to higher dimensional spaces, think of a long excel spreadsheet with many numbers in it.

But how can we finesse linear algebra and jump straight from the coordinates defined with basis $$\mathcal{B}$$ to coordinates defined with basis $$\mathcal{C}$$.

$$\vec{b}_{1} = \begin{bmatrix} -1\\-1\\2 \end{bmatrix} = s_{11}* \vec{u}_{1} + s_{21}*\vec{u}_{2} = s_{11}* \begin{bmatrix} -2\\-2\\4 \end{bmatrix} + s_{21}*\begin{bmatrix} 0\\1\\-1 \end{bmatrix} $$

From the above equation one can see by inspection or solve to find that $$s_{12} = -\frac{1}{2}$$ and $$s_{22} = -2$$.

WeBWorK 6: Problem 3 

I am confused by this question, doesn't every span/ subset have an infinite number of vectors? (unless it only contains the zero vector)

For example if a span only covers e1 then it would still need to include k(e1) to be closed under scalar multiplication. Since k can be any number, or alternatively an infinite amount of numbers. The span would cover an infinite number of vectors.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork_and_gateway"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 104, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-28T02:58:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-29T19:52:22Z", "content": "

I advise you to reread the question. For parts 2 and 3, you can answer that there are an infinite number of vectors in the set.

About your explanation, you're right that there are an infinite number of vectors in a subspace except the trivial subspace (only the zero vector is part of the set) because of the closure property under multiplication. But there's a problem with the other section where you say that every subset has an infinite number of vectors (hint: subsets are not the same as subspaces).

(Texte original: Je te conseil de relire la question. Pour les parties 2 et 3, tu peux répondre qu'il y a un quantité infini de vecteurs dans l'ensemble.

Mais, il y a un problème avec l'autre section où tu dit que chaque sous-ensemble a un quantité infini de vecteurs (un indice: les sous-ensembles ne sont pas le même que des sous-espaces).

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-28T02:58:28Z", "content": "

We have used the term trivial in the course a few times; trivial solution, trivial linear relation, trivial kernel, and now trivial intersection. In all cases, the term trivial is closely connected to the set $$\{\vec 0\}$$. 

A system has a trivial solution if the general solution is $$\{\vec 0\}$$.
A linear relation is trivial if all teh coefficients are zero. 
The trivial kernel is when the kernel of a map is $$\{\vec 0\}$$.

The trivial intersection of the subspace is when subspaces intersect at $$\{\vec 0\}$$. only
