{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 500, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-01T17:34:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "log1f02d9gb38d", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-01T17:34:20Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "log1wkxki7g4j", "to": "log1f02a68k38c", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-01T17:48:00Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "log1wuxre0q10l", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-11-01T17:48:13Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "log3pxwhypd5mk", "to": "log1f02a68k38c", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-01T18:38:50Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "PCE", "created": "2023-11-01T17:34:20Z", "content": "

I'm not really understanding the difference between linearly independent sets and linearly independent spanning sets. In what situation are they different? How do we add vectors? Wouldn't adding such vectors cause it to be not a basis, since the vectors would be linearly dependent?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 115, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-01T17:48:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brandon Ha", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukwuxn063eb", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Camelia Karimianpour", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-01T17:48:13Z", "content": "

A set is linearly independent only if it is impossible to write any vector in the set as a linear combination of the others.

A spanning set of a subspace is a set of vectors where it is possible to write any vector in the subspace as a linear combination of the set vectors.

A linearly independent spanning set is one that satisfies both these conditions.

(Texte originale - Un ensemble est indépendant linéairement uniquement s'il est impossible d'écrire n'importe quel vecteur dans l'ensemble en forme d'un combinaison linéaire des autres. Un ensemble engendré d'un sous-espace est un ensemble des vecteurs où c'est possible d'écrire n'importe quel vecteur dans le sous-espace en forme d'un combinaison linéaire de vecteurs d'ensemble. Un ensemble engendré indépendant linéairement est un ensemble qui rempli ces deux conditions.)

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-01T17:48:00Z", "content": "

A set is linearly independent only if it is impossible to write any vector in the set as a linear combination of the others.

A spanning set of a subspace is a set of vectors where it is possible to write any vector in the subspace as a linear combination of the set vectors.

A linearly independent spanning set is one that satisfies both these conditions.

(Texte originale - Un ensemble est indépendant linéairement uniquement s'il est impossible d'écrire n'importe quel vecteur dans l'ensemble en forme d'un combinaison linéaire des autres.

Un ensemble engendré d'un sous-espace est un ensemble des vecteurs où c'est possible d'écrire n'importe quel vecteur dans le sous-espace en forme d'un combinaison linéaire de vecteurs d'ensemble.

Un ensemble engendré indépendant linéairement est un ensemble qui rempli ces deux conditions.)

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukwuxn063eb", "jvbpijsmgxy40f"], "children": [], "id": "log1wkxgdjs4i", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-01T18:38:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Kate Lu", "endorser": {"lcgnjpjimjl20x": 1682647941}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l5lpb0fj1l4165", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Brandon Ha", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukwuxn063eb", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-01T18:38:50Z", "content": "

Let's fix a subspace first. Say the subspace we are in is $$\mathbb  R^2$$.

The set $$\{\begin{bmatrix}1\\2\end{bmatrix}\}$$ is linearly independent but it does not span $$\mathbb R^2$$. Hence it is not a spanning set for $$\mathbb R^2$$.

However, $$\{\begin{bmatrix}1\\2\end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix}3\\4\end{bmatrix}\}$$ is both linearly independent and it spans $$\mathbb R^2$$. 

The set $$\{\begin{bmatrix}1\\2\end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix}3\\4\end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix}1\\1\end{bmatrix}\}$$ still spans $$\mathbb R^2$$, but is not linarly independent anymore. 

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["l5lpb0fj1l4165", "lm7ukwuxn063eb"], "children": [], "id": "log3pxwffz95mj", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "log1f02a68k38c", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176295910, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"

Let's put it in terms of R3. If I asked you to think of some planes in R3 such that their intersection is just the origin, you would need at least three of them. This is because the intersection of two planes can only be a plane (if they're the same plane) or a line, (assuming the planes are subspaces) and you would need a third plane, such that that previous line isn't on the plane, for the intersection to be just the origin.

\n

\n

So, in the context of the question, we're asking something similar about R6. How many hyperplanes do you need for their intersection to just be a plane?

2b) How would you limit the amount of soot formation while still burning the fuel? Show this by using linear algebra. 

Since we are given C4H10 + O2 → CO + H2 + C from (2), then it means if the reaction is incomplete, then C(s) can be formed. And we know that incomplete reactions occur when the air-to-fuel ratio is low, meaning there is insufficient oxygen.

1) Are we assuming that the reaction will always take place under a low air-to-fuel ratio environment? In other words, we are restricted to a scenario where the reaction will always be incomplete?

2) Or can we assume that the incomplete combustion can convert to complete combustion? Because if we control the ratio of O2 and fuel C4H10 that react, such as increasing the amount of O2, then we can reach complete combustion, which minimizes the amount of C produced. 

Thank you in advance. 

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Written Homework 4 Question 1b", "created": "2023-11-01T22:30:47Z", "content": "

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["hw4"], "nr": 512, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-02T04:32:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "logoxyaqhpn7cw", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-02T04:32:55Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "data": "loh94ctajk27c9", "to": "logoxyall1o7cv", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-02T13:57:46Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lohb33rg5hq5ov", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2023-11-02T14:52:47Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "HW4 Problem 1: subspace", "created": "2023-11-02T04:32:55Z", "content": "

For both (1)(c) and (2)(a) of problem 1, it is stated that all possible stoichiometric coefficients for the reactions create a subspace. However, since stoichiometric coefficients have to be positive integer, would that not satisfy the definition of a subspace?

For example, a hypothetical vector <1,1,1,1> is a set of possible coefficient. However, it is impossible that k<1,1,1,1> is also a set of possible coefficient if k is negative or contains decimal places, like <-1,-1,-1,-1> and <1.5,1.5,1.5,1.5> are not possible coefficients. So may I know how could this satisfy the definition of a subspace?

Thanks!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["hw4", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Michael Cheng", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukyo3net3km", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Shereef Shabaka", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm775joq7exta", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Toon Craps", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 218, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-02T13:57:46Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Michael Cheng", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukyo3net3km", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Toon Craps", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Nithura Thevarajah", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk96a8bm1dp", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-02T14:52:47Z", "content": "

For our purposes, we will ignore the rule that stoichiometric coefficients must be positive integers.

In this question, we are interested in the set of mathematically valid solutions. The set of physically possible solutions is always a subset of teh set of mathematically valid solutions due to the physical constraints. 

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-02T13:57:46Z", "content": "For our purposes, we will ignore the rule that stoichiometric coefficients must be positive integers"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukyo3net3km", "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "lm7uk96a8bm1dp"], "children": [], "id": "loh94ct6idn7c8", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ukyo3net3km", "lm775joq7exta", "lm7ukr1754d2wl"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "logoxyall1o7cv", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176308858, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Hello,

\n

I\u2019m having trouble figuring out what to do to limit the amount of soot formation, how would we approach this problem?

The beginning of the problem explains:

The way I interpreted this is that [255, 0, 0] is written in the standard basis of R3. Thus [255,0,0] written in RBG basis would be [1,0,0].

However this interpretation doesn't seem to match with part 3. Where it explains:

The way I interpreted this is that [0, 255, 255] is in RBG, not that standard basis of R3. However, I feel like this doesn't make sense. Rather, it should be [0,225,255] is in the standard basis, so that Cyan's RBG coordinates would actually be [0,1,1] rather than [0,255,255]. 

I was just wondering if someone could clarify these interpretations.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukotj9jp2qd", "subject": "Homework 4, Problem 3, RBG Basis", "created": "2023-11-02T19:28:14Z", "content": "

The beginning of the problem explains:

The way I interpreted this is that [255, 0, 0] is written in the standard basis of R3. Thus [255,0,0] written in RBG basis would be [1,0,0].

However this interpretation doesn't seem to match with part 3. Where it explains:

The way I interpreted this is that [0, 255, 255] is in RBG, not that standard basis of R3. However, I feel like this doesn't make sense. Rather, it should be [0,225,255] is in the standard basis, so that Cyan's RBG coordinates would actually be [0,1,1] rather than [0,255,255]. 

I was just wondering if someone could clarify these interpretations.

I'm specifically confused by what the colours "cyan," "magenta," and "yellow" are in the CMY basis, as this information is not given and is required to determine the scaling factor of the transformation.", "created": "2023-11-02T22:33:11Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lm7ul6ini0p4au", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 1, "id": "lohrj6c3h741h2", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2023-11-02T22:41:55Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

This would imply that the basis for RBG is e1 e2 and e3 right?

However, during the office hours of another professor, they explained the basis for RBG would be vectors (255,0,0) (0,255,0) and (0,0,255).

They explained in an RBG basis, the coordinates of that vector represent the amount of red, blue and green. Where "one value of red" is represented by (255,0,0) and so on. So if you were to have the color red, it would be represented by (1,0,0) as written in the RBG basis, not (255,0,0). 

I was just wondering which interpretation is correct? Because it seems there are mixed understandings even between professors?

What about the combustion reaction is being monitored? Just how much is left? And when it says "you can assume that the reactions proceed according to the stoichiometric ratios," does that mean the ratios developed in the previous questions? As in, assume it will be balanced?

I'm not sure exactly what you mean. For an n x m matrix, you would usually say its size is n x m. As in, you'd have to include both of them.

\n

Alternatively, we often refer to the rank of a matrix, which is a concept much like dimension. In that case, m is not necessarily the rank, but it is the maximum possible rank of the matrix.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-03T19:33:05Z", "content": "

\n

Alternatively, we often refer to the rank of a matrix, which is a concept much like dimension. In that case, m is not necessarily the rank, but it is the maximum possible rank of the matrix.

I have two questions regarding Problem 3 in the assignment. 

For Part 4, should the transformation from the friends phone to the Instagram image be expressed in RGB or CMY basis?

For Part 1 and 5 where it asks for the image of the transformation, is it safe to use span[vector]? I feel span implies that we can multiply the vector by any scalar multiple, but technically the RGB or CMY values cannot go below 0 or exceed 255. Should we state restrictions and express the image as a set? Or is span okay?

Another way to write this problem is "how can we create a subspace that includes nothing from the secret plane but the zero vector?"

(Un autre manière d'écrire ce problème est « comment peut-on créer un sous-espace qui n'inclure rien du plan secret que le vecteur nul? »)

To understand better, think of this example in $$R^3$$. Imagine that we have a line and we want to find a plane which intersects it only at $$(0,0,0)$$. The easiest way to do this is to use the direction vector of the line as the normal of the plane. We can do something similar, but in $$R^6$$ instead of $$R^3$$.

(Pour le comprendre mieux, pense à cet exemple en $$R^3$$. Imagine qu'on a un ligne et qu'on veut trouver un plan qui l'intersecte seulement à $$(0,0,0)$$. Le méthode le plus facile est de utiliser le vecteur de direction du ligne pour le normal du plan. On peut faire quelque chose similaire, mais en $$R^6$$ à la place de $$R^3$$.)

(I think this is accurate.)

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-04T03:54:11Z", "content": "

(Un autre manière d'écrire ce problème est « comment peut-on créer un sous-espace qui n'inclure rien du plan secret que le vecteur nul? »)

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-04T03:44:37Z", "content": "Un autre manière d'écrire ce problème est « comment peut-on créer un sous-espace qui n'inclure rien du plan secret que le vecteur nul? »"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["ljx6wo4i1o45qa"], "children": [], "id": "loji3jdennw4la", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "In @527 it says that the normal equation of the plane is not possible anymore because we are in R6, does this mean I take the dot product?", "created": "2023-11-04T04:09:56Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Manahil Saeed", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm562039i1l1bg", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Berdan Stamov", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukqsgkf22vy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Oui, tu as raison qu'un normal unique d'un plan n'existe pas en $$R^6$$; ce que je voulais dit était qu'on peut utiliser le sous-espace perpendiculaire au sous-espace qu'on veut exclure pour créer notre sous-espace désiré.

You are right that a unique normal of a plane does not exist in $$R^6$$; what I wanted to say was that we can use the perpendicular subspace to the subspace we want to exclude to create our desired subspace.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures"], "nr": 542, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-04T07:59:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lojr7fq5kw87jd", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-04T07:59:36Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kehnb0fgkg55og", "data": "lolsrd8zo3gou", "to": "lojr7fq299l7jc", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-05T18:18:37Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "A quick question regarding determining the image of a transformation with the matrix", "created": "2023-11-04T07:59:36Z", "content": "Do we find the image of a transformation by converting its matrix to its RREF and finding its pivot columns? In other words, is the image of a transformation the span of its pivot columns?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Tashrifa Muhit", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm6q97pl63md9", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Daisy Huang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul59tsv847h", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Tharinsa Withanage", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm2n795hd584e", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 164, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-05T18:18:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Shaheen Ali Yar", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm5cgk9mzcv59j", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Jaewon Shon", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukwctwd63cu", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kehnb0fgkg55og", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-05T18:18:37Z", "content": "

Technically you don't really need to go so far. The span of all the column vectors is the image of the transformation.

\n

\n

If you need to find the\u00a0basis of the image, then you will need to remove redundant vectors, and find the minimum set of column vectors that span the space. Column vectors are redundant when they can be expressed as linear combinations of other column. In other words, when column vectors are not linearly independent, then you will need to find the RREF which gives the number of vectors in the basis (i.e. the dimension of the image).

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm5cgk9mzcv59j", "lm7ukwctwd63cu"], "children": [], "id": "lolsrd8vv00ot", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm6q97pl63md9", "lm7ul59tsv847h", "lm2n795hd584e"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lojr7fq299l7jc", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176341249, "default_anonymity": "no"}

I'm not sure how to generate three difference bases for problem 2c. I found a spanning set containing only two vectors so I'm not sure how to form that into three bases. Unless I'm doing something wrong."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["hw4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 146, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-06T22:04:22Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-06T22:04:22Z", "content": "

\u00a0Try to use the basis you already have to generate vectors in your subspace.\u00a0

\n

\n

A basis for a subspace is any spanning set for the subspace that is also linearly independent. There are infinitely many bases for a given subspace.\u00a0 Once you know the dimension of your subspace, you know exactly how many vectors you need to create a basis. It only remains to check whether they are linearly independent or a spanning set.

Hello,

Thank you.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["hw4", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Tashrifa Muhit", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm6q97pl63md9", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 128, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-04T22:12:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Wareesha Ahsan Qureshi", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukfk6s2j1x2", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Ayushi Agrawal", "endorser": {"ljajlq9tev95ta": 1690404149}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljpjslc4th91wm", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Camelia Karimianpour", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ul39yvv6410", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-04T22:12:36Z", "content": "

Rank-Nullity Thereom states that for some $$T: \mathbb{R}^{n}\to \mathbb{R}^{m}$$, $$dim(ker(T)) + dim(im(T))) = n$$. Think about what your $$n$$ would be given the space that the hyperplanes lie in and what your $$dim(ker(T))$$ should be based on the fact that the soloution is a Two-Dimensional subspace and you should be able to solve for $$dim(im(T))$$ which will indicate the min number of planes required. 

I dont think for this particular problem you would need to find a linear map with an actual "formula" but just define some $$T: \mathbb{R}^{n}\to \mathbb{R}^{m}$$ that takes hyperplanes and outputs a two-dimensional plane as a subspace of your original space 

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukfk6s2j1x2", "ljpjslc4th91wm", "jvbpijsmgxy40f"], "children": [], "id": "lokloegqnu6pv", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm6q97pl63md9"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lokk1ylonqbhm", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176350961, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Hi, 

Could someone please clear up my confusion? If my question is too answer-specific I would like to read a reply after the WH4 deadline. 

Problem 3 Q1 asks us for the basis of the linear transformation. However, my understanding was that a basis must be a spanning set (ex. if the basis describes a subspace in R^1 then it must span all of R^1). How could we have a basis for RGB if the values must be between 0-255 by definition? 

Thanks

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["hw4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 164, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-04T21:32:54Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "jia yi Xu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljv7m5l01vv4yy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Toon Craps", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Deena Abrari", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukrjw9d22xr", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Daniyaer Dilimulati", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lmhs666216z10a", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukgl49p220m", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-04T21:32:54Z", "content": "I asked the TAs the same question and they said that we can ignore the restriction of the values lying between 0-255. For the context of the question and assignment, you are allowed to assume that the basis spans R3."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["ljv7m5l01vv4yy", "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "lm7ukrjw9d22xr", "lmhs666216z10a"], "children": [], "id": "lokk9d4a3pf471", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-06T22:09:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Toon Craps", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-06T22:10:42Z", "content": "

A basis is only defined for a subspace. You can not have a basis for a linear transformation. In Question 3, you are given two bases for $$\mathbb R^3$$. One of the bases is called RGB, and the other is called CMY.  

In part 1, you are asked to find the image of a given linear map, described in one of these bases (RGB). Since the image of a map is a subspace, you describe it using a basis. Hence you are asked to find a basis for the image of the given map. 

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-06T22:09:50Z", "content": "

A basis is only defined for a subspace. You can not have a basis for a linear transformation. In Question 3, you are given two bases for $$\mathbb R^3$$. One of the bases is called RGB, and the other is called CMy.  

In part 1, you are asked to find the image of a given linear map, described in one of these basis (RGB). Since the image of a map is a subspace, you describe it using a basis. Hence you are asked to find a basis for the image of the given map.

Dividing by magnitude is the way to do it. The formula in the student's answer is correct, but we are all happier if we have to remember fewer formulas. 

Say $$\vec v_1=\vec u_1/\|\vec u_1\|$$ and  $$\vec v_2=\vec u_2/\|\vec u_2\|$$. Then $$\{\vec v_1,\vec v_2\}$$ is orthonormal and  

$$ \vec v=\vec v\cdot \vec v_1 \vec v_1+\vec v\cdot \vec v_2\vec v_2 $$

Now, since you want $$\vec v$$ as a linear combination of $$\vec u_i$$'s and not $$\vec v_i$$, let's replace $$\vec v_i$$'s with $$\vec u_i/\|\vec u_i\|$$. You will get the formula in the students answer. 

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-06T23:49:44Z", "content": "

Dividing by magnitude is the way to do it. The formula in the student's answer is correct, but we are all happier if we have to remember fewer formulas. 

Say $$\vec v_1=\vec u_1/\|\vec u_1\|$$ and  $$\vec v_2=\vec u_2/\|\vec u_2\|$$. Then $$\{\vec v_1,\vec v_2\}$$ is orthonormal and  

$$ \vec v=\vec v\cdot \vec v_1 \vec v_1+\vec v\cdot \vec v_2\vec v_2 $$

Now, since you want $\vec v$ as a linear combination of $$\vec u_i$$'s and not $$\vec v_i$$, let's replace $$\vec v_i$$'s with $$\vec u_i/\|\vec u_i\|$$. You will get the formula in the students answer.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork_and_gateway"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 127, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-05T22:55:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Aadavan Konganapuram Vasudevan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukt2fxpd31m", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lke5st586dh3aa", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-05T22:55:42Z", "content": "

for the vector v=[ 3 3 -3]
we can calculate the dot product of v with every vector in W

v·(x, y, x+y)= 3x+3y +(-3) * (x+y)
= 3x+ 3y -3x -3y =0

for v to be orthogonal to W, the dot product should be zero for all vectors (x, y, x+y) in W. in this case. the dot product is always zero, no matter of the values of x and y.

therefore v= [ 3 3 -3] is orthogonal to W

hope this helps!

That leaves you with one option. All you must do now is verify the line of intersection has a direction vector parallel to the one given by the question."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7uk5zgqoey3"], "children": [], "id": "lonr1eeoezdfa", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Just a question for the students answer. When the normals of 2 planes are not parallel that does not necessarily mean that the 2 planes will intersect at a line.", "created": "2023-11-07T14:36:01Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "From my understanding, two planes in R3 can intersect in the following ways:
1. Coincident
- parallel normal vectors
- solution is a plane

2. Parallel but not coincident
- parallel normal vectors
- no solution

3. Intersecting at line
- non-parallel normal vectors
- solution is the line of intersection

Hope this helps!

So, if I understand correctly you are thinking about a linear transformation given by left multiplication by its standard matrix. Let's say $$T(\vec x)=A\vec x$$, and you want to describe the image and the kernel of $$T$$ as a span of a number of vectors. 

The first step in understanding why we do what we do to find these subspaces in terms of the span of vectors is to write down the definitions of the image and kernel of $$T$$.

Image of $$T$$: By definition, the image of T is the set of all outputs of $$T$$. Since you know that your $$T$$ is given by multiplication by $$A$$, the image is all possible $$A\vec x$$, where $$\vec x$$ ranges over the domain. Now your job would be to interpret $$A\vec x$$ as a linear combination of the columns of $$A$$ and connect that to the definition of span. 

Kernel of $$T$$: By definition, the kernel of $$T$$ is the set of all input vectors that are mapped to teh zero vector. Now going back to the fact that you have a matrix for your map, that translates into the general solution to $$A\vec x=\vec 0$$. So to find the kernel you have to solve this linear system 

Takeaway lessons:
1) ALWAYS try to articulate the question as completely as you can. Start with what is given and what is the goal. Most often just the act of formulating a well-written question answers your question. 

2) If there is a technical term in your problem, clearly write its definition and then connect teh definition with the situation you are in (for instance here the set of all output being all possible $$A\vec x$$ or the zeros of $$T$$ being the solution to a system).

The moment you put your glasses on, however, your $$ILS$$ signal changes, and the question essentially wants you to find the matrix of some $$T: \\mathbb{R}^{3}\\to \\mathbb{R}^{3}$$ that takes the original $$ILS$$ as the input and returns the new $$ILS$$ transformed due to the glasses. What the solution essentially does is it takes the inverse of the $$RGB \\to ILS$$ matrix $$P^{-1}$$ to create a new mapping $$ILS \\to RGB$$ to find the $$RGB$$ associated with your known, original $$ILS$$, applies the blue light filter to this $$RGB$$, then turns this new $$RGB$$ back into the new $$ILS$$ so that you have a mapping that goes directly from $$ILS \\to ILS$$"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukv9h2c438k", "hzu7xmq0s9o2ow"], "children": [], "id": "lopbnbnyf0n5qf", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ukv9h2c438k"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lop7vsroh2t4qy", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176383379, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Hi!
So first, the change of basis matrix from B to C is the matrix that columns are coefficients of vectors when we write vectors in B as linear combination of vectors in C.

let's say the given two basis are:
$$B={(-1,1), (3, -4)}, C={(1,-1), (1,-2)}.$$

let's write (-1,1) as linear combination of vectors in C.
so $$(-1,1)=a(1,-1)+b(1,-2)$$

$$(-1,1)=(a+b,-a-2b)$$

so we can find the a and b values, a=-1, b=0
then the first column is $$\binom{-1}{0}$$

we can write (3,-4) as linear combination of vectors in C like how we did before
so $$(3,-4)=a(1,-1)+b(1,-2)$$
and by solving these two systems of equations, we get a=2, b=1
then the second column of the matrix is $$\binom{2}{1}$$

then we can conclude that the required change of basis matrix from B to C is $$[id]_{C}^{B}=\begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2\\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$$

you can repeat for part b

also the basis I used for example is not same, hope this helps

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lke5st586dh3aa", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-08T07:26:35Z", "content": "

Are row vectors used when the question involves a basis?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Javeria Rashid", "endorser": {"ljajlq9tev95ta": 1689021907, "global": 1691952516}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljqmhr1vwkc1b0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 125, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-08T15:59:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-08T21:09:17Z", "content": "There is no recipe or formulaic way as to when to use what. How to use information stored in a matrix always depends on the analysis of the situation you are in where you are trying to get to.\u00a0


Having said that, $$A$$ and $$A^T$$ represent two different linear transformations. There is a beautiful connection between how their kernel and image are situated in the respective domain and codomain. This connection is demonstrated in a Theorem in Pre Class Reading 8 in Expand, where we connect the orthogonal complement of the column space of $$A$$ to the kernel of $$A^T$$. The transpose matrix is involved in inverting n\u00d7n matrices using the determinant, as shown in this Khan Academy video: https://www.khanacademy.org/math/algebra-home/alg-matrices/alg-determinants-and-inverses-of-large-matrices/v/inverting-3x3-part-2-determinant-and-adjugate-of-a-matrix

Although it is probably more practical to use the typical method of augmenting the matrix with the identity matrix to find the inverse.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exams", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 95, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-08T18:28:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-08T18:28:57Z", "content": "One approach is to visualize what these planes should be, and them write their equations."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "loq3g73bjde46u", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-08T18:30:52Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brian Harilal", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lcovl1vrqk86bx", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-08T18:30:52Z", "content": "Our solution must satisfy the following:
x = 0
z = 0
y = anything (free variable)

I would take a more abstract approach proving the 3 properties to the fifth and sixth options, but it really comes down to understanding that the kernel refers to the set of vectors in the domain that become 0 after the transformation, while the image is the set of vectors in the codomain that can be obtained by transforming some vector in the domain.

  • option 5 (the kernel of T: R5→R6 is a subspace of R5):
    • a) $$\overrightarrow 0$$ must be mapped to $$\overrightarrow 0$$ (in the kernel)
    • b) vectors added together in the domain R5 will remain in R5 (the kernel is the set of vectors in R5 that becomes 0 after the transformation)
    • c) similar to (b), because the vectors (of the kernel) must initially be in domain R5, multiplying them by a scalar would result in another vector in R5
  • option 6 (the image of T: R5→R6 is a subspace of R5):
    • the image is in a higher dimension (R6) than R5 which the question asks if it is a subspace of. The zero vector in R6 may not have anything mapped to it (not surjective), adding vectors in R6 would not result in a vector in R5, and multiplying a vector by a scalar in R6 would not result in a vector in R5.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-08T21:05:39Z", "content": "

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 588, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-08T19:35:24Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "loq5tnesc5t71k", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-08T19:35:24Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "data": "loq6w1wa1pb27x", "to": "loq5tnep7xv71j", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-08T20:05:15Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Textbook 3.2 Q4", "created": "2023-11-08T19:35:24Z", "content": "

Hello, I was wondering if someone can help me out with this question. I know a subspace need to contain the zero vector and be closed under addition and multiplication but I'm not sure how to prove if the span is/isnt a subspace. If anyone can help me out that'd be great! 

Consider the vectors v1, v2, . . . , vm in Rn. Is span (v1, . . . , vm) necessarily a subspace of Rn? Justify your answer.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Sunny Wu", "endorser": {"ljajlq9tev95ta": 1690215730, "global": 1693234144, "llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1699679968}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 81, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-08T20:05:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Sabina Parmegiani", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm2ey7drfaa7ls", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "Tianyu Zhou", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "hzu7xmq0s9o2ow", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-08T20:05:15Z", "content": "

I remember in class noting that a span is always a subspace - here is my explanation for satisfying the three criteria of a subset:
- Contains 0 vector: span is the set of all linear combinations of the vectors, so which includes multiplying all vectors by 0 to obtain the zero vector.

- closed under scalar multiplication: the product of multiplying any vector in the set by a scalar is still a linear combination (in the span) of the vectors - if it were 3 times $$\overrightarrow v_2$$ for example, the linear combination would be $$0\overrightarrow v_1+3\overrightarrow v_2+0\overrightarrow v_3+...+0\overrightarrow v_n$$

- closed under vector addition: similar to the explanation for scalar multiplication, vector addition is a fundamental part of span of the vectors through their linear combinations, so the set must be closed under scalar addition

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm2ey7drfaa7ls", "hzu7xmq0s9o2ow"], "children": [], "id": "loq6w1w6nvy27v", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["ljrlqru2ii55a3"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "loq5tnep7xv71j", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176390937, "default_anonymity": "no"}

After a lot of thinking, I realized the question doesn't even ask for the transformation itself - you just need the basis. So you just change the basis so that two vectors span the plane that is being reflected over, and you do that by solving for any two vectors using the equation of the plane. The third vector is the eigenvector of the transformation (i.e. remains on its own span after the transformation). In this case, it would be the vector normal to the plane. (1,1,1) are the coefficients of the scalar equation of that plane so that's the normal. 

In the matrix, they basically just flip the third component, which would be similar to reflecting over the x-y plane in the standard basis, while keeping the other components the same. That is a key point to understanding why the matrix is diagonal in this case.

Section 3.4 of the textbook has more questions like this, if you're looking for more practice.

Solution: I understand how they got to their answer (put coefficients into a matrix, row reduce, and find the basis vectors of the solution of the system). However I'm confused on why they did this: wouldn't this be like finding the basis vectors of the kernel?

My attempt: I also started by row reducing, but instead of finding the solution, I wrote that the column vectors (in the original matrix) corresponding to the pivot columns (in the RREF) are the basis vectors. Why is this incorrect?

Can someone explain how the idea of a function ties into transformations and image?

\n

\n

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 74, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-09T23:45:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-09T23:45:37Z", "content": "A linear transformation is a function. But not every function is linear. If you have a linear transformation from $$\\mathbb R$$ to $$\\mathbb R$$, whose image is $$\\mathbb R$$, then the map is forced to be invertible by the rank nullity theorem (think about the dimension of kernel and image and connect it to injectivity and surjectivity). However, this is not true for an arbitrary function. This is what the question wants you to notice. To find an example try to think what the graph of such a function should look like."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-09T23:45:02Z", "content": "A linear transformation is a function. But not every function is linear. If you have a linear transformation from $$\\mathbb R$$ to $$\\mathbb R$$, whose image is $$\\mathbb R$$, then the map is forced to be invertible by the rank nullity theorem (think about the dimension of kernel and image and connect it to inactivity and surjectivity). However, this is not true for an arbitrary function. This is what the question wants you to notice. To find an example try to think what the graph of such a function should look like."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "loru6js67mi6o6", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lorfuqyiuj450m", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176400651, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["logistics", "exams"], "nr": 601, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-09T18:22:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lorio47guzf1xy", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-09T18:22:47Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "data": "lormybjlvis2am", "to": "lorio47c79p1xx", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-09T20:22:41Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lorio47c79p1xx", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-11-10T02:22:35Z", "cid": "lorzt5l8cgh1m4", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lorio47c79p1xx", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-11-10T02:58:02Z", "cid": "los12qaapi54dz", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "to": "lorio47c79p1xx", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-11-10T03:14:25Z", "cid": "los1nt00i7v2nq"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Past Midterm", "created": "2023-11-09T18:22:47Z", "content": "

Thank you
"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exams", "logistics", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Angelina Zhu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukgfqdy6208", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 104, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-09T20:22:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Tianyu Zhou", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "hzu7xmq0s9o2ow", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-09T20:22:41Z", "content": "

I believe you are correct, since the matrix of the linear system is homogenous.

@590 is similar to your question, but the essence is that the question is asking for the basis for V, not an image or kernel of a transformation. Keep in mind that although there is a matrix, it is not to represent a transformation specifically, but to organize the equations, which all equal 0 as you said.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["hzu7xmq0s9o2ow"], "children": [], "id": "lormybjgo632ak", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

Can someone explain how you get the values of the basis?

", "created": "2023-11-10T02:22:35Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Just add on to the question. My understanding was that the basis only includes linearly independent vectors. After taking the RREF I have 4 free variables. 

", "created": "2023-11-10T02:58:02Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "los12qaapi54dz", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2023-11-10T02:58:02Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

I hope this makes it clear, the process involves using the coefficients of the parametrized equations to create the basis vectors.

As for the part about linearly independent vectors, because the matrix is homogenous (i.e. the constants are all 0), the basis we are solving for to obtain the solution is the basis of the kernel. 4 free variables means that there are 4 basis vectors for the kernel (dimension of null space is 4).

Please let me know if this doesn't make sense.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["webwork_and_gateway", "lectures", "tutorials", "practicals", "exams"], "nr": 602, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-09T19:15:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 1, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lorkjou5a2f6ju", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-09T19:15:19Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lorlwvlm7p84wg", "to": "lorkjou0g3s6jt", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-09T19:53:34Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lorkjou0g3s6jt", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-11-09T20:34:51Z", "cid": "lorndyvfnas4ju", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lorp5czbt6q172", "to": "lorkjou0g3s6jt", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-09T21:24:09Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lorkjou0g3s6jt", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-11-09T21:25:56Z", "cid": "lorp7nzlsogzz", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Orthogonal compliment and kernel", "created": "2023-11-09T19:15:19Z", "content": "Is the orthogonal compliment of a vector in a subspace just the span of the kernel/null space because when you take the dot product of a vector and it’s kernel it equals zero? I’ve also read that it’s the kernel of the transpose but I’m not sure if that’s the same thing as what I described above. "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exams", "lectures", "practicals", "student", "tutorials", "webwork_and_gateway"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nancy Shnoudeh", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukjvoh1c2b2", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Karun Krishnavelautham", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk2vfpgdpw", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 103, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-09T19:53:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-09T19:53:34Z", "content": "The null space is the orthogonal complement to the row space, while the left null space (or the kernel of the transpose) is the orthogonal complement to the column space. "}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lorlwvljp1c4wf", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "What does orthogonal compliment to the row space mean? Is that what I described in my question? ", "created": "2023-11-09T20:34:51Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

I am not sure what you were describing because you said 'a vector in a subspace' without directly identifying which subspace you were talking about. The column space, row space, null space, and left null space are all subspaces which contain vectors. 

To identify why the row space is an orthogonal complement to the null space, consider the equation Ax=0. To compute the matrix-vector multiplication of Ax, we compute row 1 of A 'dot' x = 0, row 2 of A 'dot' x = 0 ... row m of A 'dot' x = 0. Given that we know two vectors are perpendicular if their dot product is zero, we can see that the row space would be an orthogonal complement to the null space. 

", "created": "2023-11-09T21:25:56Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lorp7nzlsogzz", "updated": "2023-11-09T21:25:56Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 1, "id": "lorndyvfnas4ju", "updated": "2023-11-09T22:34:40Z", "config": {}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-09T21:24:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-09T21:24:09Z", "content": "

Orthogonal complement is defined for a subspace, and not for a vector. You can talk about the orthogonal complement to the span of a vector for instance. It seems that your question is about the connection between the orthogonal complement of the column space of a matrix and the kernel of its transpose.  Let $$A$$ be a matrix. then $$col(A)^\perp=\ker (A^T)$$. You can read the proof in Post class reading 8 under expand. 

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lorp5czaa5h171", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ukjvoh1c2b2", "lm7uk2vfpgdpw"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lorkjou0g3s6jt", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176406058, "default_anonymity": "no"}

\n

For anyone who watched 3Blue1Brown's video on cross product and the volume of a parallelepiped (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BaM7OCEm3G0&ab_channel=3Blue1Brown), the final expression for the determinant here is confusing to me because he doesn't subtract the y(v3w1-v1w3), but we were taught that it was similar to a chessboard, where it alternates signs down the column and across row. What is the connection between our method and his?\u00a0

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 70, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-09T21:57:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Tianyu Zhou", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "hzu7xmq0s9o2ow", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-09T21:59:48Z", "content": "I think the negative sign is implied in the inverse orientation of which terms to multiply and subtract, so you can either inverse this orientation and have all plus signs, or take the same orientation for each but the y will need to be minus."}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-09T21:57:47Z", "content": "I think what he is doing is alternating the multiplication for the 'y' term. You can see this if you draw sort of a bow from v3 to w1 to v1 to w3, the ends of the bow will be oriented the opposite way compared to the x and y terms (where for x you can draw a bow from v2 to w3 to v3 to w2). Basically I think the negative sign is implied in the inverse orientation of which terms to multiply and subtract, so you can either inverse this orientation and have all plus signs, or take the same orientation for each but the y will need to be minus.\u00a0"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["hzu7xmq0s9o2ow"], "children": [], "id": "lorqcmb5hti2hr", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Oh wait I'm stupid lol I didn't read it properly. Basically it's saying that the magnitude of the cross product is equal to the magnitude of v multiplied by the magnitude of w, which is then multiplied by the sin of the angle in between v and w. The angle between v and w will never be smaller than 0 but never bigger than pi, because it doesn't make sense if it lies outside of that range. As for why the area of the parallelogram is equal to the magnitude of the cross product, look at how the area of the parallelogram is calculated. You can essentially think of it as v(perp) onto w, which is equal to magnitude of v multiplied by sin theta (base is w, height is v*sin theta). The first half is definition, the second half can be thought of visually.\u00a0"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukwuxn063eb", "hzu7xmq0s9o2ow"], "children": [], "id": "lorzf6ut6ff3b2", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Why is it multiplied by sin?", "created": "2023-11-10T02:13:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Imagine just a parallelogram in space. "}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["hzu7xmq0s9o2ow"], "children": [], "id": "los3ulkf8pb700", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-10T09:41:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "hzu7xmq0s9o2ow", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-10T09:41:40Z", "content": "Of course, you can generalize the idea of cross product to higher dimension, but we don't call it as cross product. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 621, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-10T15:09:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "losr7n93tmo427", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-10T15:09:41Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "losriqrrfru5z4", "to": "losr7n8zcnn425", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-10T15:18:19Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "losr7n8zcnn425", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-11-10T16:13:21Z", "cid": "losthj0xf6l57g", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "to": "losr7n8zcnn425", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-11-10T16:59:24Z", "cid": "losv4qpzkpg5z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukjfhgbd29r", "to": "losr7n8zcnn425", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-11-10T19:29:49Z", "cid": "lot0i6lwqoy6x8"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "to": "losr7n8zcnn425", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-11-10T20:54:33Z", "cid": "lot3j5gxjg72c6"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Kernel and basis", "created": "2023-11-10T15:09:41Z", "content": "

Is the basis of a subspace the same as finding the kernel of a matrix? From these 2 images, the steps to solving for the 2 appear to be identical where a matrix was made and put to rref and then solved for vectors in terms of each free variable.\u00a0

\n

\n

0412.png

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 81, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-10T15:18:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Karun Krishnavelautham", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk2vfpgdpw", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-10T15:18:19Z", "content": "Is the basis of a subspace the same as finding the kernel of a matrix?

Only if that subspace is the kernel of a linear map. In that case by definition of the kernel, the subspace will be a general solution to $$A\\vec x=\\vec 0$$.\u00a0

There are many ways of describing a substance. In general kernel and image of linear maps are subspaces.\u00a0

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7uk2vfpgdpw"], "children": [], "id": "losriqrmlu85z2", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "What would be an example of when it will be different, if the steps to solving the two are the same, wouldn't the 2 always be the same?", "created": "2023-11-10T16:13:21Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Let $$\\vec v_1, \\vec v_2, \\vec v_3$$ be vectors in $$\\mathbb R^4$$ then $$V=\\mathrm{Sapn}(\\vec v_1, \\vec v_2, \\vec v_3)\\subseteq \\mathbb R^4$$ is a subspace. This is not a priory connected to any linear map. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 622, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-10T15:39:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lossa3tv3mg6jm", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-10T15:39:35Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "data": "lot0fayghq43ei", "to": "lossa3trtck6jl", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-10T19:27:35Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lossa3trtck6jl", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-11-13T15:48:45Z", "cid": "lox2xg79d2p3rs", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "to": "lossa3trtck6jl", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-11-13T16:04:31Z", "cid": "lox3hqb05fv4v"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "3.4 Textbook Question Q 39", "created": "2023-11-10T15:39:35Z", "content": "

Hello,

I was doing the textbook questions for chapter 3.4 of the textbook and I'm struggling to understand the steps involved to solve problem 39 (I've attached the question as an image). Do I take the standard matrix of a reflection in R3 and what is meant by a diagonal matrix?

Thank you!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Javeria Rashid", "endorser": {"ljajlq9tev95ta": 1689021907, "global": 1691952516}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljqmhr1vwkc1b0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 114, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-10T19:27:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Manahil Saeed", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm562039i1l1bg", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "Tianyu Zhou", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "hzu7xmq0s9o2ow", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-10T19:27:35Z", "content": "

Like the midterm question that many people have asked about, you don't actually have to find the matrix of the transformation for this question. I was just working through this section too, and it is a bit tricky. 

A diagonal matrix is a matrix which has non-zeroes in the diagonal entries and zeroes everywhere else. To ensure that the matrix for T is diagonal, for this question about reflecting over a line, one of the basis vectors should be parallel to the line, while the other two are simply two different perpendicular (dot product with first vector = 0), non-zero vectors (in R3). You can see that the solution shows exactly that:

For questions about reflecting over a plane in R3, you just take two vectors that span the plane (by subbing in two values into the equation of the plane and solving for the third value, to obtain two linearly independent variables), and then the normal vector to the plane, which would be the cross product of the two vectors that span the plane, or more simply, the coefficients of the variables in the scalar equation of the plane.

Let me know if this makes sense.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm562039i1l1bg", "hzu7xmq0s9o2ow"], "children": [], "id": "lot0faybwy53eh", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "You stated that for the basis 1 of the vectors has to be parallel to the line while the other 2 are perpendicular. How exactly do you know that the vectors of the basis must correspond to this? ", "created": "2023-11-13T15:48:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

By using these basis vector, your transformation matrix becomes diagonal. This is because a linear combination of the vectors can be used to reflect a vector across the line. The coefficients of the vectors in the linear combination would then correspond or have some sort of relation to the values in the diagonal I believe.

Here you can see a very rough sketch of what I mean (ignore the pink highlighter vector, that one is a poor reflection). If I start with the green vector, then reflect across the line to get the red vector, it can be obtained by a linear combination of the vectors that the plane (perpendicular to the line) is spanned by. This is my understanding of it, though I'm not entirely sure what the matrix would look like.

I want to give additional question to this response:

I am pretty sure you can have multiple different bases for the same subspace. But I’m confused what kind of form do they take? 


Is it: a basis with respect to a certain coordinate?

I think you can have infinitely many different bases for the same subspace. They just have to spanning the entire subspace and be linearly independent.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["ljqmhr1vwkc1b0"], "children": [], "id": "loszvtb872w5o7", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-10T20:03:12Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-10T21:44:54Z", "content": "

The image and kernel of a linear transformation are completely different subspaces of possibly different $$\mathbb R^n$$. It seems that you are asking for a different basis of the SAME subspace. 

Once you have the dimension of a subspace, you know how many vectors are in any basis of that subspace. It is enough to pick that many linearly independent vectors in that subspace. You can do this in infinitely many different ways. 



"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-10T20:03:12Z", "content": "

Once you have the dimension of a subspace, you need how many vectors are in any basis of that subspace. It is enough to pick that many linearly independent vectors in that subspace. You can do this in infinitely many different ways.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Aqsam Chaudhary", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul1sqfpt3ux", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Tashrifa Muhit", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm6q97pl63md9", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Audrik Choudhury", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukn2d4i02kz", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 73, "children": [{"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-11T04:35:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Tianyu Zhou", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "hzu7xmq0s9o2ow", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-11T05:29:26Z", "content": "

I think writing it out like this makes it more clear:

$$[T]_U=S_{E→U}[T]_ES_{U→E}$$, where S became $$S_{U→E}$$ and S inverse is the opposite, $$S_{E→U}$$

Understand that the transformation T is a transformation relative to the standard basis. That means it will only have the intended effect of transformation on vectors only with the basis vectors e1, e2; any other transformation being the same would be a coincidence. In other words, if we tried to apply it directly to a vector in the basis U, it would not work properly. 

To be able to apply the transformation matrix to a vector in basis U, we first apply the matrix for changing a vector from U to E, which makes the vector in basis E. From there, we can apply T as usual because it works as expected in the basis E. Afterwards, we will rewrite the vector back in basis U, by using change of basis matrix E to U.

Hope that helps!

Update: I tried making a visual explanation with a projection in R2, but I'll admit I'm not sure if the math here is right:

If this turns out to be correct (or likely there is something wrong as it's not "clicking" for me conceptually), let me know.

I think writing it out like this makes it more clear:

$$[T]_U=S_{E→U}[T]_ES_{U→E}$$, where S became $$S_{U→E}$$ and S inverse is the opposite, $$S_{E→U}$$

Understand that the transformation T is a transformation relative to the standard basis. That means it will only have the intended effect of transformation on vectors only with the basis vectors e1, e2; any other transformation being the same would be a coincidence. In other words, if we tried to apply it directly to a vector in the basis U, it would not work properly. 

To be able to apply the transformation matrix to a vector in basis U, we first apply the matrix for changing a vector from U to E, which makes the vector in basis E. From there, we can apply T as usual because it works as expected in the basis E. Afterwards, we will rewrite the vector back in basis U, by using change of basis matrix E to U.

Hope that helps!

I think writing it out like this makes it more clear:

$$[T]_U=S_{E→U}[T]_ES_{U→E}$$, where S became $$S_{U→E}$$ and S inverse is the opposite, $$S_{E→U}$$

Understand that the transformation T is a transformation relative to the standard basis. That means it will only have the intended effect of transformation on vectors only with the basis vectors e1, e2; any other transformation being the same would be a coincidence. In other words, if we tried to apply it directly to a vector in the basis U, it would not work properly. 

To be able to apply the transformation matrix to a vector in basis U, we first apply the matrix for changing a vector from U to E, which makes the vector in basis E. From there, we can apply T as usual because it works as expected in the basis E. Afterwards, we will rewrite the vector back in basis U, by using change of basis matrix E to U.

Hope that helps!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exams", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 64, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-11T04:23:24Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Tianyu Zhou", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "hzu7xmq0s9o2ow", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-11T04:23:24Z", "content": "

We know that the coordinates of $$\left[x\right]_{\mathfrak{B}}$$ consist of two values, so there are two vectors in the basis $$\mathfrak{B}$$ (I'll call them $$b_1$$ and $$b_2$$). We also know that $$\left[x\right]_{\mathfrak{B}}=\begin{bmatrix} 2\\3 \end{bmatrix}$$, so $$x=2b_1+3b_2$$. If we rearrange the equation, we arrive at $$b_2=\frac{1}{3}(x-2b_1)$$. Replacing $$b_1$$ with $$v$$ gives us the equation in the answer.

In general, when we have coordinates in a basis and in the standard basis, this means that the linear combination of basis vectors with specified coefficients produces the vector in the standard basis. With this, we have to solve the equation for the unknown basis vectors.

In this example, we are given information that the Transformation T will project all the input vectors onto the span(u) which is given by the vector u= (3,1). First, draw the span(u) so you can visualize it better. The span of u will be the line with the direction vector u=(3,1) through the origin. 

Then to find the standard matrix, you would simply use the projection formula to compute the projections of e1 onto span(u) and then e2 onto span(u). The projections of e1 and e2 will become the columns 1 and 2 of your standard matrix. 

Similarly, the example then states that we can find the projection matrix of the transformation T with respect to a different Basis. Where originally we would use the standard basis, we will now be using Basis U (highlighted) that is given to us. It is important to note that Basis U is also an orthogonal basis. 

Then based on the fact that U is an orthogonal basis, upon observation you can conclude that the projection of vector u1 in basis U onto span(u) will give you 1, while the projection of vector u2 in basis U onto span(u) will give you 0, because of the orthogonal relationship they have. 

If you wanted to compute the matrix of T with respect to basis U, then the steps you would take would be to first, find the projections of vectors in basis U onto span(u) using the projection formula. Then write the projection with respect to the basis U by writing the projections as linear combinations of the vectors in Basis U and finding the coordinates (c1, c2). 

You will get the same matrix [T]u. 

Let me know if that makes sense.

There was a similar thing to this in Tutorial 5 DEV.

Let's start by writing everything in terms of the detA:

  • detB=-detA because R2 and R3 are swapped, which multiplies the determinant by -1, and adding another row (or a multiple of another row) does not alter the determinant.
  • detC=2detA because R1 swaps with R2, which multiplies det by -1, then the new R2 swaps with R3, which multiplies det by -1 again, meaning the deteminant is no longer negative. Then, the first row is multiplied by a scalar 2, which has the effect of multiplying the determinant by 2, and add the third row to the first row which does nothing to the determinant.

Now, we are given detA=4, so detB=-4, detC=8.

Part 1: we just solved it! detC=8

Part 2: determinant represents geometrically the ratio of volume change, so use the corresponding determinants like so: Volume = (detA)(detB)(initial volume) = (4)(-4)(5) = -80, and I guess they just took the absolute value.

Part 3: use the property det($$C^{-1}B$$)=det$$C^{-1}$$detB. The determinant of the inverse of a matrix is the reciprocal of that matrix's determinant, so det$$C^{-1}$$=1/8. Multiply det$$C^{-1}$$detB=(1/8)(-4)=-1/2

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-11T04:24:41Z", "content": "

There was a similar thing to this in Tutorial 5 DEV.

Let's start by writing everything in terms of the detA:

  • detB=-detA because R2 and R3 are swapped, which multiplies the determinant by -1, and adding another row (or a multiple of another row) does not alter the determinant.
  • detC=2detA because R1 swaps with R2, which multiplies det by -1, then the new R2 swaps with R3, which multiplies det by -1 again, meaning the deteminant is no longer negative. Then, the first row is multiplied by a scalar 2, which has the effect of multiplying the determinant by 2, and add the third row to the first row which does nothing to the determinant.

Now, we are given detA=4, so detB=-4, detC=8.

Part 1: we just solved it! detC=8

Part 2: determinant represents geometrically the ratio of volume change, so use the corresponding determinants like so: Volume = (detA)(detB)(initial volume) = (4)(-4)(5) = -80, and I guess they just took the absolute value.

Part 3: use the property det($$C^{-1}B$$)=det$$C^{-1}$$detB. The determinant of the inverse of a matrix is the reciprocal of that matrix's determinant, so det$$C^{-1}$$=1/8. Multiply det$$C^{-1}$$detB=(1/8)(-4)=-1/2

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm6q97pl63md9", "lm5cgk9mzcv59j", "hzu7xmq0s9o2ow", "l7zca5v3mwo56"], "children": [], "id": "lotjm0tn17t3m1", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["l79f0oonxcv9r"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lotfzwz58yp4pg", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176443903, "default_anonymity": "no"}

This question requires us to find a basis where the matrix of the $$T$$ transformation is a diagonal matrix; this means that non-zero values are found only on the diagonal of the matrix.

In the context of a transformation, a diagonal matrix means that each coordinate of the vector after the transformation depends only on the corresponding coordinate before the transformation.

For example, imagine we have the vector $$\begin{bmatrix}2\\3\end{bmatrix}$$ which becomes $$\begin{bmatrix}5\\4\end{bmatrix}$$ after a transformation $$T$$; if the matrix of $$T$$ is diagonal this means that $$5=2c_1$$ and that $$4=3c_2$$ for constants $$c_1, c_2$$.
