You are looking for all the 2-dimensional vectors which get mapped to the zero vector. The question tells you that the kernel must contain the aforementioned vector, so effectively, all scalar multiples of that vector must also be in the kernel, and the dimension of this kernel space would be 1 (based purely on the information from this screenshot).

The two solutions provided do not explicitly define the kernel, they just frame the problem of what you are looking for in two ways (left side solution says you are looking for all vectors which map to the zero vector; the right side solution (although not fully correct) seems to suggest that you're looking for vectors that when multiplied by that matrix, yield the zero vector). 

I hope that this helps!

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exams"], "nr": 779, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-16T17:14:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lp1gb7vzhi1480", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-16T17:14:27Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lp1j9u6sfi9a4", "to": "lp1gb7vv3u247z", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-16T18:37:22Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lp1jamb8svo26e", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-11-16T18:37:58Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Midterm 2022 6C", "created": "2023-11-16T17:14:27Z", "content": "

Can someone explain why V is equal to nullA^T, and how that equates to the perpendicular of the Col(A)? I understand how they get to the final answer after that step, they evaluate the perpendicular for each of them, how I fail to see how they set the initial equation in the first place.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exams", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Wayne Wang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukvh0wvv39a", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 127, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-16T18:37:22Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Reuben Jacob", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljq05yh6jty1yw", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Wayne Wang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukvh0wvv39a", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-16T18:37:58Z", "content": "

recall that any vector in V dot any vector in V^perp is 0.

suppose matrix A = [v, u], V = span(v, u) and let's call any vector from V^perp x. the dot product equations would leave you with:

x1v1 + x2v2 ... + xnvn = 0

x1u1 + x2u2 ... + xnun = 0

believe it or not, turning this back into a matrix provides you with A^transpose = 0. this generalizes for any number of columns.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-16T18:37:22Z", "content": "

recall that any vector in V dot any vector in V^perp is 0.

suppose matrix A = [v, u], V = span(v, u) and let's call any vector from V^perp x. the dot product equations would leave you with:

x1v1 + x2v2 ... + xnvn = 0

x1u1 + x2u2 ... + xnun = 0

believe it or not, turning this back into a matrix provides you with A^transpose = 0, and this generalized for any number of columns.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["ljq05yh6jty1yw", "lm7ukvh0wvv39a"], "children": [], "id": "lp1j9u6p7l1a3", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ukvh0wvv39a"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lp1gb7vv3u247z", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176597308, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exams"], "nr": 780, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-16T17:54:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lp1hqianiiu1lh", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-16T17:54:20Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lp1jjenkq7o6a0", "to": "lp1hqiakm7l1lg", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-16T18:44:48Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lp1jjvs966b7en", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-11-16T18:45:10Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lp1jl0fr9an2de", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-11-16T18:46:03Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Midterm2021 3(b)", "created": "2023-11-16T17:54:20Z", "content": "

I keep getting a matrix with all value 1/2 in the "orthogonal projection onto y=x" part. What is wrong?

I suppose that projection onto y=x is the same as projection onto u=<1, 1>, and the length of u is sqrt(2), so u1^2/sqrt(2)^2 is 1/2, and the rest values in the matrix is the same. 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exams", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 146, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-16T18:44:48Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Wayne Wang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukvh0wvv39a", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-16T18:46:03Z", "content": "

the span of the image is the same but the projection is not orthogonal.

try drawing out the standard unit vectors and the projection line on a piece of paper. now draw the projection AT A RIGHT ANGLE. you'll find that both project orthogonally to <cos(pi/4), cos(pi/4)>, since there's a 45 degree angle between the standard vectors and y=x.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exams"], "nr": 781, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-16T18:49:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "data": "lp1jp078bp82fa", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-16T18:49:09Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lp1jx7m7jef6qq", "to": "lp1jp075zll2f9", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-16T18:55:32Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lp1jzrnftq862i", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-11-16T18:57:32Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lp1k4y09f7i2hf", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-11-16T19:01:33Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "data": "lp1k5rj88h1bt", "to": "lp1jp075zll2f9", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-16T19:02:11Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lp1k6i32dl3629", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-11-16T19:02:46Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "subject": "set of vectors such that determinant equals 0", "created": "2023-11-16T18:49:09Z", "content": "

From the 2018 final exam, what is this question asking for and how would you approach it?

My instinct is to try subbing in some vector for a b c, and that most likely results in the equation being false. Not sure if that is what the question wants.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exams", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 122, "children": [{"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-16T18:55:32Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Sunny Wu", "endorser": {"ljajlq9tev95ta": 1690215730, "global": 1693234144, "llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1699679968}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-16T19:02:46Z", "content": "

the question asks whether the set of possible <a,b,c> of this equation is a subspace.

if the determinant is zero it's non invertible and so the kernel is a line in subspace R. in other words <a, b, c> is a linear combination represented by span(<2, 3, 1>, <-1, 1, -1>). that qualifies as a subspace of R^3.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-16T19:01:33Z", "content": "if the determinant is zero it's non invertible and so the kernel is a line in subspace R. in other words <a, b, c> is a linear combination represented by span(<2, 3, 1>, <-1, 1, -1>). that qualifies as a subspace of R^3."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-16T18:57:32Z", "content": "if the determinant is zero it's non invertible and so the kernel is a line in subspace R. in other words <a, b, c> is a linear combination. that qualifies as a subspace of R^3, since the span of the other two vectors is also a subspace of R^3."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-16T18:55:32Z", "content": "if the determinant is zero it's non invertible and so the kernel is a line in subspace R. in other words <a, b, c> is a linear combination. that qualifies as a subspace of R^3."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["ljrlqru2ii55a3"], "children": [], "id": "lp1jx7m3m8e6qp", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-16T19:02:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Sunny Wu", "endorser": {"ljajlq9tev95ta": 1690215730, "global": 1693234144, "llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1699679968}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-16T19:02:11Z", "content": "(Basically what Zain said)

Determinant being zero means it's not invertible. For a 3x3 matrix, this is when the rank isn't 3. Since the first two columns are linearly independent, the rank is already at least two, and it would only not be 3 if the third column is in the span of the first two columns.

Therefore, the span of the other two columns is the set of vectors that would make the determinant equal to zero. This is a subspace because it's a plane passing through the origin."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["ljrlqru2ii55a3"], "children": [], "id": "lp1k5rj6pu91bs", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lp1jp075zll2f9", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176599471, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exams"], "nr": 782, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-16T19:36:54Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "data": "lp1leerwca6g5", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-16T19:36:54Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "data": "lp1oxypoa4v1ou", "to": "lp1leeroifag4", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-16T21:16:06Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "subject": "matrix A = 0 e1 e2...", "created": "2023-11-16T19:36:54Z", "content": "

Could someone let me know if my answers to this question make sense?

a) T(x)=Ax

b) A^2=$$[\overrightarrow 0\space \overrightarrow 0\space \overrightarrow e_1...\space \overrightarrow e_{n-2}]$$

c) basis for col(Am) would be vectors e1 to $$\overrightarrow e_{n-m}$$, basis for null would be $$\overrightarrow e_{m-n+1}$$ to e_m

d) m=n

what does it mean here by an eigenvector being associated with an eigenvalue? would it mean the eigenvector that you would directly get from substituting the eigenvector back into A-λI=0 and getting the solution, or can it also be a scalar multiple?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 98, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-19T18:41:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Sunny Wu", "endorser": {"ljajlq9tev95ta": 1690215730, "global": 1693234144, "llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1699679968}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-19T19:03:40Z", "content": "

An eigenvalue implies the scalar by which an eigenvector is scaled (so Av=lambda*v). I think to solve this we multiply each vector with the given matrix A, and see if this result is equal to multiplying each vector with the 'associated eigenvalue' given in each line of the question. For example, Av=1*v hence 1 is the associated eigenvalue for v.

Edit: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cdZnhQjJu4I&list=PLE7DDD91010BC51F8&index=22&ab_channel=MITOpenCourseWare

This from timestamp 12:00-12:30 has the exact same example.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork_and_gateway"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 112, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-20T18:23:52Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-20T18:25:35Z", "content": "

Hi, 

I gave it a try using the fact that det(A-I*lambda) = 0 and substituted the small number as x, eventually to show that for det(A-I*lambda) = 0 , x= -24. There's probably a faster way that I don't know but at least you don't have to compute the determinant with the small number. I used cofactor expansion to find det, not certain if it's correct but my reasoning is that lambda is not an eigenvalue if x does not equal the small number.

Hi, after solving for eigenvalues, lambda=0 ends up in the characteristic polynomial. When I input this into Webwork it marks it correct, but shouldn't eigenvalues !=0 since then any vector could be an eigenvector?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork_and_gateway"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 85, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-22T03:15:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Zain Glover", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm0p9o3xo7a2jo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Camelia Karimianpour", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Ali Alizada", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l79f0oonxcv9r", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-22T03:15:40Z", "content": "

Hi, 

When an eigenvalue = 0, I think this implies that the eigenvector is in the kernel of the transformation. Remember that if an eigenvalue = 0 for some vector v1, then A*v1 = 0. Not every arbitrary vector will satisfy A*v = 0, so not any vector here could be an eigenvector (though there could be infinitely many eigenvectors with an eigenvalue = 0 where infinitely many != every vector). In this case, we care about finding an eigenbasis.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["webwork_and_gateway"], "nr": 831, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-23T22:09:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpbqy19mqrf6mu", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-23T22:09:50Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lpbsdp1ysbh43g", "to": "lpbqy19js846mt", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-23T22:50:00Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lpbsdwhzxr94cx", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-11-23T22:50:10Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lpbsfkzlit66ia", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-11-23T22:51:28Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lpbvdy16btf50f", "to": "lpbqy19js846mt", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-24T00:14:11Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Trace and Determinant's relation to eigenvalue", "created": "2023-11-23T22:09:50Z", "content": "Can someone explain the relation between trace and determinant? In webwork problem 12, you are given the trace and determinant of a 2x2 matrix and are supposed to find the eigenvalues. After searching online, I found that the trace is equal to the sum of the eigenvalues, and the determinant is the product of the eigenvalues. But how is this proven?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork_and_gateway"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 117, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-23T22:50:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-23T22:51:28Z", "content": "

Hi, 

Hopefully this video supplies what you are looking for: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e50Bj7jn9IQ&list=PLZHQObOWTQDPD3MizzM2xVFitgF8hE_ab&index=15&ab_channel=3Blue1Brown

I am not sure if your question implies you know what the trace is; if not: 

The trace of a matrix A is the sum of all of the components of its diagonal (where i = j). This value equals the sum of the eigenvalues of the transformation. 

As you state, the determinant of A equals the product of the eigenvalues. 

Thus we have

eigenvalue1 + eigenvalue 2 = C for some constant C = trace(A)

eigenvalue1*eigenvalue2 = Det(A) = D for some constant D

We have two unknowns and two equations and can solve. 

Alternatively the video presents a quicker method for calculating eigenvalues associated to a 2x2 matrix, the formula of which is:       m +- sqrt(m^2-p) where m = trace(A)/2 and p = Det(A)

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["webwork_and_gateway"], "nr": 846, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-25T19:32:06Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpeg6w09njg1nh", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-25T19:32:06Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "data": "lpftglelwvm1am", "to": "lpeg6w05y7u1ng", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-26T18:31:20Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Problem 2 Webwork 9", "created": "2023-11-25T19:32:06Z", "content": "For the second part of the question, I was wondering how we should solve for Ax."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork_and_gateway"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 105, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-26T18:31:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-26T18:31:20Z", "content": "

We know that v1, v2, and v3 return scalars of themselves when we multiply with matrix A. We also know that the given vector x can be written as a linear combination of v1, v2, and v3.

So we can say if x = c1(v1) + c2(v2) + c3(v3), then A(x) = A(c1(v1) + c2(v2) + c3(v3)).

Using the properties of linear transformations, you should be able to apply matrix A to v1, v2, and v3. With some arithmetic and the values you solved for the in the first part, you can find A(x). 

Hope this helps!

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lpftgleh3fe1al", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpeg6w05y7u1ng", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176669662, "default_anonymity": "no"}

For (1) does it want two pairs of vi and vj? Also do the eigenvectors represent a singular student?
For (2) is that a representation of one student or a pair of students?
For (4) How do I use the lecture_list.mat file to assign colours to the scatter plot

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["hw5", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Carolina Fischmeister", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uksc5ok22zt", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Grace Li", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljrxkk8gcuz4hw", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Grace Lin", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul4axlho44n", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 174, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-27T19:37:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jqmt4g7ji644z5", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-27T19:37:20Z", "content": "

For (1):

You would need to extract two eigenvectors; The ith value from the first one will represent an X coordinate (vi) and the ith value from the second one other will represent a y coordinate (vj) for a singular student.

(2) A single student as mentioned above.

(4) See the MATLAB documentation on colour here: https://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/ref/scatter.html#btrj9jn-1-c

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures"], "nr": 861, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-26T16:25:08Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ul2ljapm3yb", "data": "lpfoyayhdq95lz", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-26T16:25:08Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lpg7wgrgmhtnj", "to": "lpfoyaye7175ly", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-27T01:15:35Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lpg7yhu93yr4s8", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-11-27T01:17:09Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ul2ljapm3yb", "subject": "Diagonizability and Eigenbasis; bidirectional relationship?", "created": "2023-11-26T16:25:08Z", "content": "

Hello all, 

I am reading the PCE for Week 11 and stumbled on this statement on page 3:

"Thus T does not have an eigenbasis and is therefore not diagonalizable."

However, we have no iff statement or theorem. The second theorem on the same page states that "If T:Rn > Rn has n distinct eigenvalues then T is diagonizable."

Does this relationship go both ways? That is, if the matrix has n distinct eigenvalues and therefore has an eigenbasis, the transformation matrix for T is diagonalizable, AND if the matrix is diagonalizable, it MUST have an eigenbasis and therefore three distinct eigenvalues. 

So diagonalizable means eigenbasis exists, and eigenbasis exists means diagonalizable?

Cheers.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Tashrifa Muhit", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm6q97pl63md9", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Zain Azam", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 87, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-27T01:15:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Vanik Park", "endorser": {"llax09p5hb11ji": 1700489272}, "admin": false, "photo": "1694737851_200.jpg", "id": "lm7ul2ljapm3yb", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/lm7ul2ljapm3yb/1694737851_200.jpg", "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Deena Abrari", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukrjw9d22xr", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-27T01:17:09Z", "content": "

your last statement is correct. it's true that any diagonalizable matrix has an eigenbasis and vice versa.

however the statement about eigen values does NOT go both ways. have a look at these two matrices:


$$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$$ $$\begin{bmatrix}2 & 1 \\ -1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$$


recall the theorem about algebraic versus geometric multiplicity. these have the same exact nondistinct eigenvalues with the same exact algebraic multiplicity. one is diagonalizable. one is not. try solving for eigenvectors.


distinct eigenvalues $$=$$ eigenbasis $$=$$ diagonalizable.
diagonalizable $$=$$ eigenbasis $$\neq$$ distinct eigenvalues.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-27T01:15:35Z", "content": "

your last statement is correct. it's true that any diagonalizable matrix has an eigenbasis.

however the statement about eigen values does NOT go both ways. have a look at these two matrices:


$$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$$ $$\begin{bmatrix}2 & 1 \\ -1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$$


recall the theorem about algebraic versus geometric multiplicity. these have the same exact nondistinct eigenvalues with the same exact algebraic multiplicity. one is diagonalizable. one is not. try solving for eigenvectors.


distinct eigenvalues $$=$$ eigenbasis $$=$$ diagonalizable.
diagonalizable $$=$$ eigenbasis $$\neq$$ distinct eigenvalues.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ul2ljapm3yb", "lm7ukrjw9d22xr"], "children": [], "id": "lpg7wgrbtyhni", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm6q97pl63md9", "lm7uk89v8yl1an"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpfoyaye7175ly", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176685859, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["webwork_and_gateway"], "nr": 873, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-27T02:54:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpgbf374url6j", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-27T02:54:02Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ljraydvfg2u3ap", "data": "lpgbo0es9kf2f", "to": "lpgbf371nqi6i", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-27T03:00:59Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WW 9 Q 9", "created": "2023-11-27T02:54:02Z", "content": "

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork_and_gateway"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 79, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-27T03:00:59Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Wareesha Ahsan Qureshi", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukfk6s2j1x2", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljraydvfg2u3ap", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-27T03:00:59Z", "content": "So here I'm assuming you have no idea of how to find the eigenvector, so lemme start from here.

To find the Eigen vector, with provided eigenvalue, you could construct a matrix that is equal to A - λI, and λ stands for the eigenvalue, after this, by applying the formula (A-λI) · v = 0, v here will be your eigenvector, therefore you could get the augmented matrix will the last column to all be 0, and then, do the rref, solve for the null space of the matrix, and that will be your eigenvector.

By considering the multiplicity, times your eigenvector by the multiplicity, you should be able to get the right answer.

Correct me if there is anything went wrong."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukfk6s2j1x2"], "children": [], "id": "lpgbo0eot6r2e", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpgbf371nqi6i", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176698812, "default_anonymity": "no"}

What do you have as the given matrix A? I'm not seeing a matrix as 'given' on my screen.

But, what you do know about A is the eigenvectors and what eigenvalues they correspond to. Remember linearity, and remember what an eigenvalue means graphically. (By which I mean, remember that an eigenvalue is the factor by which its eigenvectors are scaled when they undergo the transformation).

\n

\n

With that in mind, what can you say about A(v1 + v2)?

\n

Hi. My question is, iff an n by n matrix Q has n orthonormal vectors, then it is orthogonal matrix, right? Does it mean that a matrix with n orthogonal vectors (but not orthonormal) is not considered as "orthogonal matrix"?

the problem could be that by default, matlab shows all matrices in the form $$k\begin{matrix}[a ... b]\end{matrix}$$ where $$a$$ and $$b$$ are to a certain number of decimal places. so if $$a >> b$$ then $$b$$ will appear to be zero. I changed the output to scientific notation by running

format short g

Is it really true? How do I prove that?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 80, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-28T19:18:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-28T19:18:10Z", "content": "This statement is not true (take the first example in Introduce as a counter-example). {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures"], "nr": 944, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-30T00:10:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpkfvw5v5vh5tj", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-30T00:10:10Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "data": "lpklp91o7556ab", "to": "lpkfvw5s6jx5ti", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-30T02:52:57Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Orthonormal Eigen Basis", "created": "2023-11-30T00:10:10Z", "content": "why do we need to apply gram Schmidt method to 3 or more Eigen spaces to create an orthonormal basis for an eigen matrix when according to the PCE a symmetrical matrix ( which can only be orthogonally diagonalizable) has eigen spaces which are already orthogonal to one another. Why don\u2019t we just scale the magnitudes instead ?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 88, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-30T02:52:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-30T02:52:57Z", "content": "If your eigenspace for some particular \u03bb is greater than 1-dimensional, then you will need to apply gram schmitt to find an orthogonal set of eigenvectors that are a basis for this eigenspace.\u00a0

Two different eigenspaces are always orthogonal if your matrix is symmetric, so you only really need to apply gram schmitt on the individual eigenspaces.\u00a0
"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lpklp91ly846aa", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpkfvw5s6jx5ti", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176775486, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "tutorials"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Jiaying Dou", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljo7qmxghwe1u6", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 107, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-30T03:05:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Jiaying Dou", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljo7qmxghwe1u6", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kf2z2j444pg31s", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-30T03:05:28Z", "content": "

Notably, we know that the image is defined by the Column space (span of the columns). 

It turns out that $$L$$ is the only matrix whose column space is different than the other matrices. To observe this, try and see if you can write the columns of a given matrix as a linear combination of another matrix's columns.

Hope this helps.

If you are referring to part b, then consider the following.

What does $$M \begin{bmatrix} a_1 \\ a_0 \end{bmatrix}$$ output? What about $$M^2 \begin{bmatrix} a_1 \\ a_0 \end{bmatrix}$$? Try and observe how applying $$M$$ affects the indices of the $$a$$ terms in the input.

Once you have an idea of this relationship, it should be evident what $$k$$ is. Let me know if you have further questions.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other", "webwork_and_gateway"], "nr": 951, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-30T03:09:49Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk25qpxknv", "data": "lpkmaxpftsh3kl", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-30T03:09:49Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk25qpxknv", "subject": "Is there an effective way to find the eigenvalues of a 3x3 symmetric matrix?", "created": "2023-11-30T03:09:49Z", "content": "

Hi there. For this matrix, I know the way of `det(A - λI) = 0` and solve the polynomial, but is there any trick to solve that?

so far I know that we can get one eigenvalue, λ=4,  by simply "look at it", and then I can devide the cubic polynomial by (λ-4), and then solve for the quadratic polynomial... but is there a more effective way? I don't want to unwind the polynomial because it requires a heavy calculation.

I'm wondering if there is a trick to tackle with a symmetric matrix

Midterm II not showing?

"lm7ul4igh6u45b", "subject": "Error in Midterm II posted solutions", "created": "2023-11-30T05:39:27Z", "content": "

For Part B, question 4 the answer listed on the posted solutions is "True," however, there is a clear error in this claim.

The question asks us to determine whether the following syllogism is true:

Premises:

A is an invertible matrix

B is an invertible matrix

Conclusion:

AB is an invertible matrix

To show a mathematical claim is false, we must show that it does not always hold.

Consider the following case:

A=I₂

B=I₃

A and B clearly meet both premises of the question. The identity matrix of dimension 2 is invertible, and the identity matrix of dimension 3 is invertible. Then, by virtue of what the question is claiming, we must be able to conclude, based on this information alone, that the conclusion listed above is true.

Does the listed conclusion hold? That is, is AB invertible? No, it does not hold.

AB=I₂I₃. This does not even exist. Therefore, the conclusion "AB is invertible" is a false conclusion, which means that the mathematical claim being made in this question does NOT always hold, making the answer false.

The grading for this question should be inverted (i.e. choosing "False" should be the option graded as correct). Though this level of logical precision may have been difficult for some to notice during the test, it is completely unfair to those of us who did notice it to be deducted marks.

For additional clarification of where the mistake in the listed proof is, the mistake is in writing the equality det(AB)=det(A)det(B). The reason writing this equality is a mistake is because this equality holds if and only if the dimensions of A are equal to the dimensions of B. This is not a justified assumption. The question does not say "Let A and B be n x n invertible matrices," or anything similar that would allow us to conclude the validity of this equality.

This is not a matter of whether it is a "fair assumption". In mathematics, logical precision is essential. When a question is asking us to determine the logical validity of a claim, we cannot begin injecting arbitrary assumptions into the question. Once you begin doing that, you are solving a different question.

Based on the information provided in the question, there is absolutely zero validity in assuming that AB exists. The existence of AB is assumed in the conclusion, which means that given any two invertible matrices A and B, we must be able to deduce that AB is invertible (which, of course, implies the corollary that AB exists) without directly assuming that AB exists. This is not a valid conclusion, as demonstrated by the counterexample I listed (though there are infinitely many).

12/2", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lpkofx8hiej3ov", "updated": "2023-11-30T17:59:53Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

> determinant of A is non zero

Valid

> determinant of B is non zero

Valid

>determinant of AB must be non zero

Invalid.

Consider the identity matrix of dimension 2 to be A, and the identity matrix of dimension 3 to be B.

Is it valid to claim "the determinant of A is nonzero"? Yes, it is 1.

Is it valid to claim "the determinant of B is nonzero"? Yes, it is 1.

Is it valid to claim "the determinant of AB nonzero"? No. This is a false claim. Therefore, the claim made in the question, which we are being asked to determine the validity of, does NOT always hold, which makes the answer false.

To clarify the specific error in your reasoning, you need to pay careful attention to the theorem you are applying (it is in Post-Class Reading 5):

Note the constraint that A and B are n x n matrices. This constraint (or a logically equivalent constraint) is NOT provided in the question, which is why using this reasoning is flawed.

determinant of A is non zero --> given in the question (since A is invertible)

determinant of B is non zero--> given in the question (since B is invertible)

A is an identity matrix of dimension 2 --> assumption

B is an identity matrix of dimension  3 --> assumption

If you only use the info given by the question without assumption, we can determine that the determinant of AB is non-zero zero, therefore invertible. 

However, if you make assumptions, you can say that the statement is false.

But I think your post about assumptions  @957_f1 is incorrect. ", "created": "2023-11-30T04:23:17Z", "bucket_order": 9, "bucket_name": "Week 11/26 - 12/2", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lpkoxes03ow8m", "updated": "2023-11-30T05:01:35Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

> But make you made assumptions about what A is and what B is, which by your reasoning, you are solving a different question. 

This is not what "making an assumption" is. What I presented is a counterexample. 

The distinction here is that, when you make an unjustified assumption in writing a proof, you have fundamentally altered the question. Writing a counterexample, as long as it satisfies the premises in the question, is not equivalent to making an unjustified assumption within a proof.

Consider the following example:

True or false: 2a=0 for all a.

Making an assumption would be doing something like this:

"If a=0, then 2a=0 holds. Therefore, the claim is true"

This assumes a is zero, in an attempt to prove that the equality always holds. This is logically invalid.

Making a counterexample would be doing something like this:

"If a=1, then 2a=0 does NOT hold. Therefore, the claim is false"

This shows an explicit example of the claim not holding, which shows that it is not always true, and therefore the answer is "False".

The underlying point here is that, showing that a claim holds for a specific subset of values, does NOT show that the claim holds for all values.

I believe for there to be an exception to the grading scheme, it should be evident the question/solution was fundamentally incorrect.", "created": "2023-11-30T04:14:06Z", "bucket_order": 9, "bucket_name": "Week 11/26 - 12/2", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

This is not a matter of having an "exception to the grading scheme". As outlined in my original post, it is evident that the solution is fundamentally incorrect, on a purely logical basis. If a logically precise answer was beyond the scope of what most students were able to produce on this question, that does not justify grading those who answered the question in a logically valid manner incorrectly.

If you can identify any logical flaws in the argument presented in my post, I'd be happy to see it.

Please note that the "arguments" that other's have posted that amount to "it 'felt' like AB existed" is not a logical argument. A logical argument uses the information explicitly provided in the question. Injecting one's feelings into the question departs the realm of logic.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 139, "children": [{"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-30T17:16:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Sunny Wu", "endorser": {"ljajlq9tev95ta": 1690215730, "global": 1693234144, "llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1699679968}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-30T17:33:22Z", "content": "

A distribution matrix that is not regular could be A = [1 0; 0 1]

I can't think of a general way to determine if a transition matrix is regular, however I think it may be feasible for some matrix structures to determine it is irregular. Identity matrices seem irregular since they will always stay the identity matrices for any power of m. 

I also checked out a discussion online where they suggest matrices of the form [a 0 b; 0 1 0; c 0 d] are irregular since they middle row and middle column will keep the 0 1 0 structure: https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/1376828/when-to-stop-checking-if-a-transition-matrix-is-regular

Maybe someone else has a more systematic response

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-30T17:21:01Z", "content": "[removed]"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-30T17:17:28Z", "content": "

Hi, 

I was thinking about the property of a decomposition; that is, A^m can be decomposed as P*X^m*inv(P) where X is a diagonal matrix. Maybe we can find some values along the diagonal where the entries will never all be positive. Any negative number squared would be positive; any positive number squared would be positive. I think the only value that would work is zero, since zero^m for m is any real number is zero which is not positive. 

Thus maybe any transition matrix that can be decomposed so that the diagonal matrix X contains a zero along the diagonal would be irregular? 

example:    A= [0.5000   -0.5000; -0.5000    0.5000] with eig(A) = 0, 1

Does this make sense or have I made a mistake? 

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-30T17:16:42Z", "content": "

Hi, 

I was thinking about the property of a decomposition; that is, A^m can be decomposed as P*X^m*inv(p) where X is a diagonal matrix. Maybe we can find some values along the diagonal where the entries will never all be positive. Any negative number squared would be positive; any positive number squared would be positive. I think the only value that would work is zero, since zero^m for m is any real number is zero which is not positive. 

Thus maybe any transition matrix that can be decomposed so that the diagonal matrix X contains a zero along the diagonal would be irregular? 

example:    A= [0.5000   -0.5000; -0.5000    0.5000] with eig(A) = 0, 1

Does this make sense or have I made a mistake? 

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["ljrlqru2ii55a3"], "children": [], "id": "lplgk15u9u7lj", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "it seems pretty complicated. but maybe if one row / column has zeroes where the others have stuff then and if that row/column has a non-zero the others have a zero there, when multiplying through any number of times that row/column will not be affected?", "created": "2023-12-04T13:12:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Hi,

Consider [0 1 0; 0.5 0 0.5; 0.5 0 0.5] which matches your description. Its equilibrium is [0.33 0.33 0.33; 0.33 0.33 0.33; 0.33 0.33 0.33].

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures"], "nr": 967, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-30T17:57:59Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpli144797z7nd", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-30T17:57:59Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lpll5knh5fr5n1", "to": "lpli1444qi87nc", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-30T19:25:26Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lpllas87jqd63k", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-11-30T19:29:29Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lpllvrlgos77cy", "to": "lpli1444qi87nc", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-30T19:45:48Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "content question", "created": "2023-11-30T17:57:59Z", "content": "Is diagonalizing a matrix the same as finding the eigenbasis of it?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 130, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-30T19:25:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-30T19:29:29Z", "content": "

diagonalization is a step ahead of finding the eigenbasis. a diagonalized matrix $$D$$ is just the original matrix $$A$$ in the space of its eigenbasis. that's where $$D=P^{-1}AP$$ and $$A=PDP^{-1}$$ come from.

to use this formula you would need to find the change of basis matrix $$P$$ whose columns are the eigenbasis in the space of $$A$$, but $$P$$ and $$D$$ are not the same. you just use the eigenbasis to perform diagonalization.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-30T19:25:26Z", "content": "

diagonalization is a step ahead of finding the eigenbasis. a diagonalized matrix $$D$$ is just the original matrix $$A$$ in the space of its eigenbasis. that's where $$A=PDP^{-1}$$ comes from.

to use this formula you would need to find the change of basis matrix $$P$$ whose columns are the eigenbasis in the space of $$A$$, but $$P$$ and $$D$$ are not the same. you just use the eigenbasis to perform diagonalization.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lpll5kndl4w5n0", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-30T19:45:48Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-30T19:45:48Z", "content": "Conceptually yes. 

A matrix is diagonalizable if and only if the underlying linear map has an eigenbasis. "Diagonalizing" a matrix is a term used for finding that eigenbasis and finding the matrix representation of the linear map with respect to this eigenbasis. This representation will be diagonal. "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lpllvrldpnv7cx", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpli1444qi87nc", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176800350, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["hw5", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Rithvika Kathroju", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lly6utysh6g2ms", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Aadavan Konganapuram Vasudevan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukt2fxpd31m", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 158, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-01T05:07:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Justin Altimari", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukzt7hwa3o3", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ul88uwt14gw", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-01T05:07:21Z", "content": "
Dealing with an internal error in MATLAB Online can be tricky, but here are some general steps you can take to troubleshoot and potentially solve the issue:

1. Check Internet Connection: Ensure your internet connection is stable. MATLAB Online requires a constant internet connection to function properly.

2. Clear Browser Cache: Sometimes, clearing your browser's cache can resolve issues with web applications. Try this and then reload MATLAB Online.

3. Try a Different Browser: If the problem persists, try accessing MATLAB Online from a different web browser. Compatibility issues can sometimes cause errors.

4. Update Browser: Ensure that your browser is updated to the latest version. Outdated browsers may not support all the features of MATLAB Online.

5. Disable Browser Extensions: Some browser extensions can interfere with web applications. Try disabling them to see if this resolves the issue.

6. Check MATLAB Status: Sometimes the issue could be from MATLAB's end. Check their website or social media channels for any announcements regarding server issues or maintenance.

7. Restart MATLAB Online Session: Log out and then log back into MATLAB Online. A fresh session might resolve the problem.

8. Contact MATLAB Support: If none of these steps work, your best bet is to contact MATLAB support. Provide them with details of the error message and the steps you have taken to try and resolve it.

9. Check Community Forums: MATLAB has a large user community, and forums like MATLAB Central can be very helpful. Someone might have experienced a similar issue and found a solution.

Remember, internal errors can sometimes be caused by issues on the server side, which you won't be able to fix yourself. In such cases, waiting for MATLAB to resolve the issue is the only option.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures", "logistics"], "nr": 976, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-01T03:19:18Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpm22zekg4m35z", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-01T03:19:18Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lpmqkfdkocw2ob", "to": "lpm22zeffn235y", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-12-01T14:44:43Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "PCE 10 Question", "created": "2023-12-01T03:19:18Z", "content": "Hi, I just wanted to make sure if my understanding was correct for PCE 10, specifically the expand section.\u00a0

So to find the eigenvectors for a given linear transformation we have to first find its eigenvalues which can be done by computing the characteristic polynomial of the matrix.

Then using the eigenvalues you can find the eigenspace of transformation in order to find our eigenvalues. You can do this by looking for the kernel basis of A-\u03bbIn where \u03bb is some eigenvalue.\u00a0

After doing that you should get the span of some vector in which is also going to be part of your eigenbasis. And you basically repeat this process for all eigenvalues until you find all of the spanning sets of eigenvectors??

Please let me know if I am understanding this correctly. Thank you!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "logistics", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 109, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-01T14:44:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Rocky", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l7zca5v3mwo56", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-01T14:44:43Z", "content": "Yes, to find bases for all the eigenspaces of a matrix $$A$$, you find bases for the kernel of $$A-\\lambda I$$ for all eigenvalues $$\\lambda $$ of $$A$$."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["l7zca5v3mwo56"], "children": [], "id": "lpmqkfdgu3f2oa", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpm22zeffn235y", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176810092, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures", "other"], "nr": 996, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-03T05:02:08Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpp0mx7sa5b1zh", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-03T05:02:08Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lppqlhc18535za", "to": "lpp0mx7onp81zg", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-12-03T17:08:51Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lppqm2njqw66y8", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2023-12-03T17:09:18Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "PCE Week 11-Confusion regarding eigenbasis", "created": "2023-12-03T05:02:08Z", "content": "

It was my understanding that a matrix A and an eigenbasis for a matrix A represent the same linear transformation. Furthermore an orthonormal eigenbasis for matrix A also represents the same linear transformation. However see Example 3 from PCE 11 below. 

My confusion is because of the calculations I did below. I inputed the same vector into the standard matrix A, The transformation in terms of basis b, the eigenbasis B, and the orthonormal eigenbasis u. I found that none of them are mapped to the same place. Can someone please explain why that is.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures", "other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 70, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-03T17:08:51Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mark Samuel", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk1qrnpwn0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-03T17:09:18Z", "content": "" Understanding that a matrix A and an eigenbasis for a matrix A represent the same linear transformation"

This is not accurate. An eigenbasis is a basis for $$\mathbb R^n$$. It does not present a linear transformation. However, one can use it as a basis to represent a linear map by computing their output in the coordinate of the eigenbasis and writing the matrix representation of the linear map with respect to this eigenbasis. 

It seems that you are missing the following important underlying concept: $$[T]_\mathcal B$$ is the matrix of $$T$$ with respect to the basis $$\mathcal B$$. If you plug in $$\mathcal B$$ coordinates of a vector it will compute the $$\mathcal B$$ coordinate of the output of that vector for you. In your computation, you are plugging in the same coordinates into both matrices. If $$\begin{bmatrix}3\\4\\5\end{bmatrix}$$ is the standard coordinate of your vector, to be able to use $$[T]_\mathcal B$$ to find its output, first you need to find its $$\mathcal B$$ coordinate, and then you can plug it into $$[T]_\mathcal B$$."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-03T17:08:51Z", "content": "" Understanding that a matrix A and an eigenbasis for a matrix A represent the same linear transformation"

eigenbasis is a basis for $$\mathbb R^n$$. It does not present a linear transformation. However, one can use it as a basis to represent a linear map by computing their output in the coordinate of the eigenbasis and writing the matrix representation of the linear map with respect to this eigenbasis. 

It seems that you are missing the following important underlying concept: $$[T]_\mathcal B$$ is the matrix of $$T$$ with respect to the basis $$\mathcal B$$. If you plug in $$\mathcal B$$ coordinates of a vector it will compute the $$\mathcal B$$ coordinate of the output of that vector for you. In your computation, you are plugging in the same coordinates into both matrices. If $$\begin{bmatrix}3\\4\\5\end{bmatrix}$$ is the standard coordinate of your vector, to be able to use $$[T]_\mathcal B$$ to find its output, first you need to find its $$\mathcal B$$ coordinate, and then you can plug it into $$[T]_\mathcal B$$. "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7uk1qrnpwn0"], "children": [], "id": "lppqlhbvm355z9", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpp0mx7onp81zg", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176831742, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Take a map that scales by 2 in $$\mathbb R^2$$ and take any two non-perpendicular vectors.  "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ul1ukq6r3v6", "lm7ukyo3net3km"], "children": [], "id": "lpp1v5e6tc396", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "May I know are you referring to eigenvectors from the same eigenspace? If they are in different eigenspaces should they be orthogonal to each other because in this question the matrix has 3 distinct eigenvalues. ", "created": "2023-12-03T05:52:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "If $$A$$ is symmetric, its eigenspaces are orthogonal. So if you pick eigenvectors from different eigenspaces (corresponding to different eigenvalues) they ought to be orthogonal. This is NOT because $$A$$ has distinct eigenvalues, this is because $$A$$ is symmetric. But if you pick eigenvectors in the same eigenspace, they may or may not be orthogonal. You can always pick an orthogonal basis for each eigenspace, and the union of all such vectors will be an orthonormal eigenbasis for the domain. ", "created": "2023-12-03T15:55:58Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lppnzr6f1fg6x2", "updated": "2023-12-03T15:55:58Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

I understand that if an eigenspace has a dimension of 2 (or higher), eigenvectors in that $$\mathbb{R}^{2}$$ eigenspace might not be orthogonal to each other even though they are not scalar multiple of each other. It could be any vector on that plane and therefore they are not orthogonal to each other. 

However, in this question, the matrix A given has 3 distinct eigenvalues and is symmetrical. This implies that there are 3 $$\mathbb{R}^{1}$$ eigenspaces. So other than picking eigenvectors that are in the same eigenspace and are scalar multiple of each other, how can they not be orthogonal?

", "created": "2023-12-03T19:11:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lppuznfgaxr4g6", "updated": "2023-12-03T19:11:50Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "A you mentioned, in a one-dimensional eigenspace you can pick eigenvectors that are scalar multiples of each other and hence not orthogonal.  There is no need for the eigenspace to be one dimensional. You can always pick eigenvectors in teh same eigenspace that are NOT orthogonal to one another. So the fact that this particular matrix has distinct eigenvalues is not relavant to this question. You can replace $$A$$ with another symmetric matrix whose eigenvalues are not distinct and all the same statements hold. ", "created": "2023-12-03T20:30:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Michael Cheng", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukyo3net3km", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ukyo3net3km"], "id": "lppxshfezks7kw", "updated": "2023-12-03T22:30:35Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpp2fc9isgl2eo", "updated": "2023-12-03T20:30:15Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ukyo3net3km", "llyo6kxhoi93sg"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpp15pxg5ym3j4", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716176833910, "default_anonymity": "no"}
